Walpole Island
Oct. 27th 1876

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

gentlemen:

Will you kindly inform me at once if I have power to send home pupils from school whose heads and bodies are infected with vermin.
Such conditions can not exist in the school room as I have already carried home on my clothing the same things awaiting your reply. I am.

Yours very truly,

S.E. Wilson

474881
Ottawa, November 3, 1915.

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 27th ultimo I beg to say that Mr. Agent McCallum will be instructed to take the necessary steps to have the heads of the children attending the Walpole Island No. 1 School properly attended to and Dr. Cathcart will be requested to visit the school and make a personal examination of their heads for pediculi. To do this the children should all be at the school at the time of his visit. Mr. McCallum has been requested to notify you of the date on which the doctor's visit will be made.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Secretary.

Miss S. E. Wilson,
Teacher,
Walpole Island No. 1 School,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Ottawa, November 3, 1915.

Sir,

Miss Wilson, teacher of the No. 1 School on Walpole Island, has written the Department complaining that many of the children in her school are affected with vermin to such an extent that she has asked permission to send some of them home.

As these insect pests are very annoying the Department would like you to call upon Dr. Cathcart to make a personal examination of the children in the Walpole Island schools and take the necessary steps to insure the eradication of pediculi. You will be good enough to inform the teachers of the date on which the doctor will visit the schools. Kindly report to the Department after his visit.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Secretary.

Theo. A. McCallum, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Sir:

Your letter received today and desire to thank you for the copy of "Regulations" regarding Indian Schools. In the future I shall know the law regarding my school and service.

Permit me to explain that when I came here, I was told that salary was paid quarterly and at the end of Sept. the amount would be paid ($150). Agent Mr. Collins told me about the Indians to my school and got his name on in but never in any way mentioned a teacher's return report. Since Sept. 30th we have been told several times that he was effecting our degrees every day — he said so.
Yesterday upon receipt of your letter I went to his house to consult him. I asked what report I was to send in. He said "I don't know". I said "what have the other girls done in the past?" "They sent reports in July and December but no other times", he said. I left the matter with him to look up.

We were both strangers in the school and it was his duty to inform us of such reports the first time at least. I had no school law in my school except the course I studied and I follow that.

I have spent my own money too freely on books, pencils, soap and clothes since I came here and I do think in such a school as this soap, clothes and towels are
absolutely necessary. I cannot teach dirty pupils.

You can rest assured that a trip I have done has been because of my interest in the pupils, and I need Agent McCallum's assistance in getting necessary articles for my school—not to be told "you will just have to wait."

My returns have been made out and I shall send to the Agent without delay—

Yours very truly,

T. E. Wilson.
Ottawa, November 10, 1915.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st instant stating that you have spent your own money too freely on books, pencils, soap and combs since you took charge of the Walpole Island No. 1 School.

In reply I beg to say that all articles of this kind for the Indian schools are furnished by the Department. If you will forward to the Department through Mr. Agent McCallum receipted accounts for any of these supplies that you have purchased you will be reimbursed for the money you have expended. In future when you require supplies of this kind you should forward a requisition to the Department through Mr. McCallum's office.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss S. E. Wilson,
Teacher,
Walpole Island No. 1 School,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Ottawa, November 10, 1915.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Miss Wilson, teacher of the Walpole Island No. 1 School, in which she states that she has spent her own money on books, pencils, soap and combs since she took charge of this school.

She has been informed that if who will forward to the Department through your office receipted accounts for any of these supplies that she has purchased she will be reimbursed for the money expended. You will be good enough to forward these accounts to the Department as soon as you receive them from Miss Wilson. She has also been informed that in future when she requires any supplies of this kind she should forward a requisition to the Department through your office.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. A. McCallum, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Sarnia, Ont.

December 12, 1914.

Mr. Theo McCallum
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.

Dear Mr. McCallum,

Replying to your of the 9th, inst., I shall write to several teachers and ask them to apply for your school. I return Miss Wilson's letter herewith.

Miss Wilson taught in S.S.No.26 Bembra, Becher, under my inspectorial supervision. She is a capable teacher and her work was good as far as I was able to observe but she did not get along well with the people.

The stories I heard about her would seem to indicate that she is not easy to live with. If you could communicate with Mr. Fred Jones by phone he would doubtless give you some information about her.

I would esteem it a favor if you would notify me when the appointment has been made. I remain

Yours very truly,

(signed) Henry Conn
Public School Inspector.
Regarding Mrs. Silver and the children in her school in regard to the school we have had three daughters here in this school since June last and we had no trouble until Miss Wilson came down enclosing letters received from me through the Public School Inspector into letters of confidential nature giving it to you confidentially and I submit it seems to me I have had to take my way out of the school the way myself not being able to control her and she needed help on a little way so when possible to get the correct feeling the Board removed from the attendance list by this means what they took me was in their way very urgent name among missing when heard at school and finally request us come into the field.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

REPORT OF INSPECTOR CONN ON THE WAIPOLE ISLAND, NO.1 school.

Miss Wilson is a capable teacher and she is doing effective work. I am very pleased with the attendance, attention she is paying to physical culture and to something hygienic. Manual training and domestic science will be taken up as soon as the necessary materials are provided.

Miss Wilson taught for a short time in one of the public schools of my inspectorate. Her record there would seem to indicate that she is not easy to get along with, and when she quarrelled with the parents, the children seemed to suffer. I am afraid-frustrated—afraid friction may develop and have thought it well that the failure of the young woman should such situation arise.

Report dated—October 25th, 1915.

Ottawa, November 30, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant in which you complain of the treatment received by your little boy at the hands of the teacher of the No. 1 School on Walpole Island.

In reply I beg to say that the teacher has been informed that she must be more careful in future to pay prompt attention to the requests of her pupils who wish to leave the school in obedience to the calls of nature if she wishes to remain in charge of the school.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. A. McCallum, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Ottawa, November 30, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant enclosing a communication sent you by Mr. Public School Inspector Conn in regard to the teacher of the No. 1 School on Walpole Island, which is returned herewith as requested.

If Miss Wilson will agree to carry out the instructions given her in letter of even date in regard to granting permission to pupils to leave the room when necessary there will be no reason for your removing your children from the school as you suggest.

When the Department wrote you on the 3rd instant instructing you to request Dr. Cathcart to make a personal examination of the children of the Walpole Island schools and take the necessary steps to insure the eradication of pediculi it was expected that he would comply with this request. As he has apparently not done so up to the present he will be written to personally and again instructed to make this inspection, as long as he remains the medical officer of the Walpole Island Band he must comply with the Department's instructions. You report the doctor as saying that he has one patient with spinal meningitis, contracted from washing her head at school. It is to prevent cases of this kind that the doctor is asked to make an examination of the pupils and prescribe

Thos. A. McCallum, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.
the necessary remedies.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Otter, November 30, 1915.

Sir,

On the 3rd of November, last, Mr. Agent McCallum was instructed to request you to make a personal examination of the children of the Walpole Island schools and take the necessary steps to insure the eradication of pediculi.

Mr. McCallum reports that he showed you the letter which was sent him on this subject and you said you wondered what they take you for.

When the letter above referred to was sent to Mr. McCallum you were and still are the medical attendant for the Walpole Island Indians and as long as you act in this capacity the Department will expect you to carry out its requests in regard to attendance on the Indians of this band. Other medical men in the employ of the Department have had similar requests made to them and have not hesitated to act on the Department's suggestions. I trust that it will not be necessary to again call your attention to the desire of the Department to have the children at these schools looked after.

All you are expected to do is to satisfy yourself as to their condition and prescribe the necessary remedies. The Department will see that your instructions are carried out.

Your obedient servant,

V. A. Cathcart, Esq., M.D.,
Port Lambton, Ont.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, November 30, 1915.

Madam,

Mr. Agent McCallum has complained to the Department that he has been forced to remove his little son, who was a pupil at your school, on account of your refusing him permission to leave the room to obey the calls of nature.

Mr. McCallum has been informed that you will be instructed to use more discretion in future and that it will not be necessary for him to keep his child away from school on this account. I trust that you will govern yourself accordingly in future.

Mr. McCallum also states that it is rumored that you do not intend to remain on at this school after the Christmas holidays. If this is the case you will be good enough to send in your resignation at once so that the Department may be in a position to look out for another teacher. If this rumor is incorrect be good enough to let the Department know that it is your intention to remain on and endeavour to work harmoniously with the Agent and the parents of the pupils attending your school.

Your obedient servant,

Miss S. E. Wilson,
Teacher,
Walpole Island No. 1 School,
Walpole Island, Ont.

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Gentlemen:

Mr. Agent McCullum called at my school today and informed me that I was not going to teach in your school for the coming year. I told him when I made my agreement with the Department? Understood it was for a year or at least until services were terminated by either party giving thirty days.
notice. Will you inform me if I am correct?

I am perfectly satisfied with conditions in my school. Between myself and Indian pupils there is perfect harmony and work with them is very interesting. No complaints have been made to me, but with out boasting in any way whatever, my work has been well spoken by Inspector Owen and Indian parents.

However, since I wrote you and enquired about my salary, Mr. Agent McCallum has taken a dislike to me and has done everything to discourage me. (Reported me to
Inspector Conn, concerning his son, came into my school room and with out any reason hurled sarcastic remarks at me before the pupils. I bore it all patiently but still it is impossible to please him.

Miss Warnock and I were hired on the same conditions but Agent McCallum failed to tell her she was not engaged for next year, so kindly let me know if I have your support and confidence in this matter or can Agent McCallum discharge me.

Walford. Yours very truly

Nov. 30th 78. H.E. Wilson
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE,

Sir,

Dear Mr. Benson,

I have a letter before me received from Mr. Scott regarding your teacher in School. I am not in a position to say what it was about, but I will say that I believe he was very kind and that he will continue doing so. We are very grateful to you for your kindness.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Ottawa, December 4, 1915.

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 30th ultimo I beg to say that the services of teachers in the employ of the Department are continued as long as they give satisfaction; should they fail to do so due notice is given them that their services will be no longer required, save in exceptional cases where they are guilty of gross misconduct which would justify the Department in their summary dismissal.

In your case Mr. Agent McCallum wrote the Department stating that it was rumored that you did not intend to remain on at this school after the Christmas holidays and he was told that if this were the case he should obtain your resignation in writing, and if the rumor was not correct the Department had no wish to dispense with your services. The Department regrets the strained relations existing between you and Mr. McCallum and he will be written to and instructed to do what he can to assist you.

Your services will not be dispensed with without due notice from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Miss G. E. Wilson,
Teacher,
Valpole Island No. 1 School,
Valpole Island, Ont. Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, December 6, 1915.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Miss Wilson, teacher of the No. 1 School on Walpole Island, in which she states that you informed her that she was not engaged to teach for the coming year.

I should like to know whether you so informed her and, if so, what authority you had for making this statement. You were advised by official letter of the 30th ultimo that, unless the teachers of the two schools on Walpole Island voluntarily resigned their positions, the Department was prepared to keep them on, as there is no good reason why their services should be dispensed with.

Since the summer holidays in 1914 we have had four teachers at the No. 1 School and when we have teachers that are competent and are willing to remain the Department considers that it is your duty to give them every encouragement instead of throwing cold water on their efforts and trying to get rid of them.

The Department has just received your report on the No. 1 School for the month of November, last, which shows that the teacher is, in your estimation, competent and no complaints have been received from the Indians. Mr. Inspector Conn, who visited this school on the 25th of October, last, states in his report that Miss

Thos. McCallum, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Wilson is a competent teacher and is doing efficient work. He mentions, however, that her record seems to indicate that she is not easy to get along with and, from correspondence the Department has received from you, Mr. Smith, has advised you to this effect. As she is a competent teacher you should, in the interests of the school, make allowance for her uncertain temper.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Walpole, Ont.

Dec. 5/15

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of November 30th last requesting a personal examination of children of Walpole Island schools, I might say that, having visited each school, the condition of the children was found to be fairly satisfactory due to the intelligent and energetic treatment carried out by the teachers.

As to the complete eradication of pediculi, a common disease, it always thrives amongst this race of people; it is impossible without the cooperation of the parents which is wanting in some homes.

I have advised the teachers on the proper procedure and prescribed the necessary remedies which will no doubt go along way in improving the condition of the children from unsatisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

W. A. Cathcart
Ottawa, December 16, 1915.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant giving your version of the occasion which led to the complaint made by Mr. Agent McCallum that he had been forced to remove his little son, who was a pupil at your school.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Agent McCallum has been informed that this matter should be dropped.

I may also say that, after the Christmas holidays, steps will be taken to see that the teachers on Walpole Island receive fair treatment so long as they remain in charge of these schools.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss S. E. Wilson,
Teacher,
Walpole Island No. 1 School,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Ottawa, December 16, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant reporting on the result of your visit to the Walpole Island Schools.

In reply I have to thank you for your action in this matter and also for your report.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. A. Oathcart, Esq., M.D.,
Fort Lambton, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I wish to call your attention to the matter in regard to our teacher No. School Nine Wilson where does she get her power to come? The school wherever she prefers. Last Friday May 12th she came here and all day she was seen going away with a suit case with Iris Roberts or Thomas also a suit case in hand to take the ferry to Algoma. Wish to wait until morning. Later it was learned she accompanied this pupil to Int. Origin Institute entitled her there as a pupil in the Chipewa's of Algoma Island. It is undesirable for this girl Iris to enter as a pupil of Int. Origin Institute and receive the equal right.
as a full member when she is not a member of Walpole Island or no other reserve.

Her mother married a white man. This case should be looked into at once & should be brought up in the Council for Consideration & let Miss Wilson give account of her self. Trusting this will be looked into at once & save the expense of the Tribe.
The Wallaceburgh Herald Record

Ottawa, June 6, 1916.

Madam,

The Department is advised that you are in the habit of closing the Walpole Island No. 1 school at half past two or three o'clock in the afternoon or for a half day and also that this school was closed all day on Friday the 12th ultimo, as you took a girl to the Mount Elgin Institute.

The Department would like to know if this is correct and, if so, what reasons you have for not keeping the school open the required time each teaching day.

Your obedient servant,

Gentlemen:

Pupils of my school have had measles for past three weeks until my numbers have decreased to five and three pupils. Of other pupils there remain but the required three weeks they will not be back during June. It will be possible for me to have space for another until September at least.

Would you deem it advisable to close
school earlier than
the usual date.
Please advise me
at once as conditions
are discouraging.

Yours very truly,
E.E. Wilson

Wallaceburg, Ont.
R.R. #3.
Ottawa, June 19, 1916.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant asking if the Department would deem it advisable to close the Walpole Island No. 1 School earlier than usual this year, as the pupils have had measles for the past three weeks and the numbers in attendance have decreased to five and three.

In reply I beg to say that the Department considers that this school should be kept open until the 30th instant, which is the regular time for closing for the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Walpole, June 14th.

Gentlemen:

Your letter today and contents noted and will endeavor to frankly explain charges against me. In the first place I have no habit of closing school at any time of the day. Since I took charge of your school one year ago, I have failed to open only one day that will be a lost day. That day I was confined to my bed.

May 12th. With the Indians' first cold wave it was difficult to keep up our part to please them. Students when a favor was asked explained the matter before my pupils and told me I would make up the day for them. So the day was not a lost day.

The day lost thirdly after I had been ice-bound in the school and living in an Indian town for weeks, I asked Mr. McCullum to close at three so I could make train connections for home. He said I could do so, I... has reported me for the same. When I returned after Easter I was absent first
morning till eleven o'clock because it could not be helped. I came to inform the day before school opened, but the river was full twice and no money we were able any one to take me there at. I went miles out of my way and much expense but I could not arrive at school at nine o'clock.

There been the custom on this island to close school on Fridays at 3:30 p.m., as a sort of reward to pupils for good work & to truly be found little done I don't see.

I have taught fifteen minutes longer on the noon hour than before too...

I think I've been lucky & my time lost my time except the day I was ill.

But not one to say I am a human being and have an conscience. I feel that I have done for more work in this school than I shall ever be paid for and few would do such work for people as we teachers & I don't care few if any—girls would stay one year and live in an Indian house. I took on my register
and see that other teachers have remained but three months here. They had a white house to board in and most of them got home every spring night.

I have done my very best to please the Department and indian parents also done my utmost to advance pupils during entire year. I hear no complaints except from the one named above. Time and again I wrote against McCollum & Co. tried to turn indian parents and pupils against me, but still they did not yield. Surely if I have made things plain to you, I am.

Yours very truly,

S. E. Wilson

Mr. Scott,

With reference to Mr. Ogilvie's report on the Walpole Island Schools I beg to say that, as regards the attendance, it has certainly been going from bad to worse. They have a truant officer there and the teachers have done their best to keep the attendance up with no encouragement from the Agent, in fact it is a question whether he has not been a hindrance. I judge this from his own reports, as nothing apparently affords him greater pleasure than noting the falling off of the attendance. He has never said anything about assisting the teachers in this direction and his attitude towards them has been such that Miss Wilson, the teacher of the No. 1 School, has sent in her resignation, asking that it take effect on the first possible. Miss Warnock, the teacher of the No. 2 School, resigned after the summer holidays and Mr. Cork, who has taken her place, is not satisfactory to Mr.

Mr. Public School Inspector Conn, in his report
on the No. 1 School states as follows:— "The pupils who were present showed satisfactory proficiency and are undoubtedly making good progress. The teacher is to be commended for the attention she is giving to hygiene and personal cleanliness. I examined samples of the pupils' works in plain sewing and am very pleased with the work that is being done. I believe the teacher is making efforts to secure better attendance, but she is not meeting with much success."

Miss Wilson may have offended some of the parents on account of her desire to have the children cleanly in their habits and person and from what I can learn Mr. McCallum is rather pleased than otherwise at the teacher's unpopularity. Inspector in a previous report on this school states that Miss Wilson is a capable teacher and doing efficient work and that he is pleased with the attention she is devoting to physical culture and hygiene. He adds that Miss Wilson is difficult to get on with. Mr. McCallum apparently never made an effort to get on with her, in fact ever since she has been there he has done what he can to make her position untenable and I am of the opinion that he is prepared to do the same with Mr. Cork."

Dear Sir -

My attention has been drawn to the resignation (afterwards withdrawn) of Miss Wilson as teacher of the Valpole Island No. 1 School, and to school conditions generally on the reserve. In so far as the educational work is concerned the reports show that Miss Wilson has been an efficient teacher. She has not, however, succeeded in making satisfactory progress owing in a large degree to the lack of regular attendance on the part of the pupils. I am forced to think that this condition is to some extent aggravated by your attitude towards the teacher and towards the work generally. I am sorry that I have had to reach this conclusion.

The educational work on the reserve is perhaps the most important in our administration, and where agents are not thoroughly in sympathy with their work and with the people, whose interests we are trying to promote, satisfactory results cannot be obtained. It is also found that you have been negligent in attending

Thomas A. Macallum, Esq.,

to details in connection with the school buildings, etc., thus hampering the work of the teachers.

Miss Wilson taught school at Walpole Island for one year and until Dec 22 she lies at present in a sanatorium in Essex Co near Kingville with tuberculosis. She was teaching in Muskoka before she went to Walpole Island and I firmly believe had she stayed there and never gone to Wal-
pole Island she would not be where she is today. She had to board with the Indians something she never should have done and was badly nourished although she paid a good place for board she had to buy milk from a white woman of take to school to exist after she got sick. The last two months she was there she should have been in bed in a hospital as she really had tuberculosis & didn't know it, as the doctor

I have been informed that Mr. Abraham reported to the Department of Indian Affairs that neither teachers nor pupils arrive at No. I School until after 9 o'clock in the morning and after 12 noon or 2 o'clock in the afternoon. I can only say that Mr. Abraham has made a very unfounded unjust report.

During the winter of 1817 I had so much trouble with pupils coming late—even those who lived nearest the school—that from December until March 1st I kept the clock fifteen minutes behind Eastern Standard Time. After March 1st the clock was advanced to the regular time.

The Indians as a rule do not come until daylight—and morning—so clocks are slow. And as there are six pupils living near the school who came to school during...
The winter months are coming a distance from me. I found that the majority of the pupils present at nine o'clock, and as the school hours were not shortened I considered the plan had to be altered. But even then some of the children were unavoidably late as owing to an unusually severe winter with drifted roads, those living at the three mile distance found it at times almost impossible to reach the school at nine o'clock. Since Easter I have not had any "lates". As a rule the majority of the pupils are both punctual and regular in their attendance from Easter until Christmas.

I had heard during Mr. Abraham's last visit he had been speaking to the Indians that I should call the school at 1 o'clock in the afternoon. The half hour period has been in force for three years, I believe, as a means of gaining the greater part of the pupils time in which to go home for their dinner.
Mr. Abraham knew last June length of the noon period and I have always treated him with courtesy. I fail to see why he should not have discussed those differences with me.

I have always been much interested in my school on this reserve and have endeavoured to be faithful in the discharge of any duties.

Respectfully Yours,

At the present time we have a Mrs. McDonald teaching in the No. 1 School, Walpole Island. For the last couple of years Mrs. McDonald has been coming late to school, sometimes a half hour and sometimes an hour late in the morning. She very seldom opens school after dinner until a quarter to two, sometimes later. The Indians have complained to me on a number of occasions and I have made a report of this to the Department before. I have been informed recently that she is still arriving late at school. Another point about Mrs. McDonald is that she never loses an opportunity to say something detrimental to the present Agent, to the Indians, which is very embarrassing at times to the Agent. On two occasions the former Indian agent, Mr. Thomas McCallum, now deceased, came to the Island and stayed over Sunday with her, alone in the Agency house. He was seen by the Indians, coming and leaving.

This sort of conduct leaves a very bad impression with the Indians. No doubt, Mrs. McDonald would deny these charges, and I have no doubt that it would be difficult for us to prove the latter. So far as her opening school late is concerned, of course, that can be proved.

I beg to recommend that Mrs. McDonald's services be discontinued this mid-summer and that the Agent be notified to give her one month's notice.

At the present time there is a Mrs. Corman teaching in the Western school at the Deseronto reserve, who, I believe, would make a splendid teacher for this school. She
has expressed the wish to be stationed on some reserve where she could assist in missionary work. The Missionary at Walpole Island, the Rev. Mr. Fortiner, has expressed the wish to have a teacher in the school who would be able to assist him in the Sunday school work. Mrs. Corman has resigned at the Deseronto school. I beg to recommend that she be engaged for the Walpole Island school.

W.H. Atkinson

Agricultural Representative.

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 19th instant, I beg to say that the return forwarded by you for the September quarter, showed that you had taught 19 days during the month. There are 200 teaching days in the school year and in the case of a new teacher the Department pays for the September quarter for the number of days actually taught during that quarter, consequently, you were paid $\frac{19}{200}$ of $550.00 which equals $52.25. From this we deduct an advance of $35.00, leaving $17.25 still due you, a cheque for which amount you have received.

For the December quarter you will be paid one-quarter of your yearly salary and a like amount for the March quarter. At the end of the June quarter, provided you have taught the full 200 days, you will be paid the balance of your yearly salary.

The September quarter bonus will be paid to teachers of Indian day schools when the December quarter bonus is being paid.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 1, in respect to the Indian Day School at Walpole Island. So far as I was concerned there was no promise to Mrs. McPherson in any way that she would have the Walpole Island school when she wished it.

The question as to whether Mrs. McPherson and her mother would be better suited to Walpole Island than Mrs. Savage and her mother live, Wells, I would not be in a position to say, as I do not know what kind of a teacher Mrs. MacDougall would make. So far as Mrs. Savage and Mrs. McPherson are concerned both are very good teachers, and both have good qualifications. Of course Mrs. Savage has a professional second class certificate, and has had many years of experience in some of the best schools in this vicinity, including a large school in the city where she taught for some years.

I understand that Mrs. Wells taught school a number of years ago. The objectionable feature in connection with Mrs. McPherson coming back, was the fact that her younger sister was too much inclined to run around with some of the Indians. Of course that objection would be removed if Mrs. MacDougall takes her place.

I think the school would be well served in either case, from the standpoint of efficiency. I do not think it would make very much difference.

Personally I would not be in favor of dismissing Mrs. Savage, as the Indians seem very well satisfied with the present conditions. The missionary just the other day

CHATHAM, ONT. April 7, 1924.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing, with this, list of the school children at Walpole Island who should be attending the local school. You will note that there are fifteen or sixteen children who have never been to school. Some of these children are 12, 13, and 14 years of age. Of course there are some of them at a considerable distance from the school, the public school. I think it would be advisable to send them to one of our residential schools.

I might say that there has been nothing done in connection with the Greenbird Williams children or the White children. I think it would be advisable to appoint a new Truant Officer. There is no excuse now at Walpole Island. There is plenty of school room for all the children. It is evident to me that the present Truant Officer is not doing his duty. I would recommend that when I am appointed a Truant Officer for the local school, also take this up. I do not see how it amounts of time the Truant Officer receives at the present time, but I believe it would be good policy to pay at least two visits per week.

I might point out that Walpole Island is an exceptionally bad condition in respect to school attendance and something should be done to relieve the situation.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have to inform you that Mrs. Harriette Macpherson, formerly Senior Teacher at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School, wishes to secure a position in one of the Indian schools at Walpole Island for the coming academic year. As you are aware, there will be one vacancy in the Walpole Island schools, as Mrs. Wells is giving up duty at the end of June.

The Department wishes to give Mrs. Macpherson's application favourable consideration. She is willing to take either room in No. 1 School or the No. 2 School. If she takes the junior room at Walpole Island No. 1, she will be content to have one of the upstairs rooms only as her share of the residence, as she would arrange to rent a cottage in the vicinity.

The Department will agree to any arrangement which is considered in the best interests of the Indian children of the Island. If Mrs. George wishes to transfer to the junior room at Walpole Island No. 1 at the same salary she is now receiving, this action can be taken. If Mrs. Savage wishes to transfer to the No. 2 School because of the better residence facilities, such action would be approved.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing, herewith, a letter which was handed to me by Walter Sands, one of the store keepers at Walpole Island.

In explanation, I might say, that Walter Sands came over to my office and told me a long story about his boy being expelled from school for misbehaviour. He stated at that time that he was ready to back the teachers in every way in trying to control the boy; he said the boy was willing to promise to be good if allowed to go back to school. I advised Mr. Sands to get in touch with the Indian Agent, Mr. Paul. You will note that his letter states that he had been in touch with Mr. Paul, but that the teachers would not allow the boy to go back to school, unless he promised not to talk about them any more. This, he claims, he refused to do on the grounds that he did not think that this had anything to do with his son's conduct.

While at Walpole Island on Monday last, I went with Mr. Paul and saw the teachers. We discussed the matter of allowing the boy to come back. Finally after a great deal of persuasion the teachers agreed to allow him to come back if he promised to behave himself, and if the father would promise to assist them in every way possible. We, therefore, brought the father and boy over to the school. The boy agreed to behave himself in the future, and the father agreed to assist the teachers as much as possible.

I might say that we asked both parties not to bring up any of their grievances at this conference, as it would only lead to further trouble. Notwithstanding this, when Walter Sands and his son were leaving, the teachers subjected him to considerable abuse, calling him a jail bird and a number of other terms to which he objected. The father then said he did not think it would be any use sending the boy back, if the teachers maintained that kind of attitude.
However, we talked it over with him and he has started the boy back to school, but I do not think the settlement between the teacher and Sands is permanent. I feel confident that the boy will be an angel if he escapes being expelled again, and the teachers will be severely condemned by Sands if his boy is punished for misdemeanor.

I believe that Mr. Paul intends writing you in regard to this as well.

You will also note in the letter that I am enclosing, that several other Indians are making complaints against the teachers. I also understand that the whole matter is to be aired in the Indian Council on Monday.

I remain

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

As you are no doubt now aware, there has been considerable trouble caused in this school by an Indian-White child—owing to the fact that I was compelled to expel his son, Emerson, for continued smoking, insolence, and insubordination during school hours.

Mr. Paul, the Indian Agent, after a consultation with the boy and his parents, upheld my decision but Mr. Brown, the agricultural agent, came to the school and insisted that I allow the boy to return, on the terms he laid down, even humiliating me to the extent of making me promise to do as the boy wished with regard to his son etc.
Since returning to school, the boy still causing trouble and consequently the discipline which has been excellent is hard to maintain. He bullies the younger children, destroyed a valuable map on a senior girl and resents any authority.

Mr. Copin, the Public School Inspector, on observing the boy's attitude in school, says he should never have been allowed in again and that upon his next offence, he should be expelled permanently and sent away to another school as the same conditions are an immoral and unfitting for the upbringing of children.

The boy, however, is rather kind-hearted, a true Christian soul which has always been a source of trouble for the Reserve. Further information to the side of the matter may be obtained from Rev. G. Clayton, United Church minister who resides next to the school or Inspector Hudson of the Canadian Mounted Police at Windsor.
Mr. Abraham instructed me not to whip the boy as this would annoy the father, but rather to overlook all his offenses which are most flagrant.

I mildly advise in this case as the boy who is 14 years old feels that he can do just as he wishes in school. While Mr. Abraham has practically laid my hands by saying I must not punish him.

I might add that I have prepared this pupil twice for his entrance examinations and he has failed both times, so little further can be done for him here along educational lines.

A number of children had the measles. And those parents who are not anxious to send their children to school, take every advantage they can of the epidemics, etc., etc. In the spring time, the water has been so high in the creeks and marshes that many of families are unable to get from the schools.

In reference to No. 3 School teachers, Mrs. MacPherson and Mrs. Macdonald.

I believe Mrs. MacPherson quite well qualified to teach any school if she would attend strictly to her duties in the school, but I have been unable to get her to keep school at anything like full time. I do not believe that the children average three hours a day in school for
the whole term. One is liable to see children in the yard playing at any time of the day, as they seem to have no regular hour for calling school or taking recess, and will dismiss school for an hour or a half a day whenever they feel so inclined; both teachers at this school have been known to close school from a day to three days at a time to go to a fair or picnic, and I have a number of dates down when school has been dismissed from an hour to a half day for no apparent cause the Teachers insist on taking one and a half hours at noon claiming the department gives them this special privilege. If the Department has granted them this privilege it is certainly all right, but Mrs. (name), teacher at No. 2 School feels that she is being discriminated against when asked to just take an hour.

Mrs. MacDougall, teacher of the junior room at No. 1 School, does not seem to have very much success advancing pupils, and seems to lack tact and in my opinion is too temperamental to be successful as a teacher.

Neither the class-rooms, the residence or the yard or outbuildings are kept very neat or attractive.

Owing to the peculiar temperament and disposition
of both Mrs. MacPherson and Mrs. MacDougall, they have become very much disliked by the majority of residents on the Reserve, and it is just under threats of taking action under Section IO of Indian Act that we have been able to keep a number of the children at school at all.

As it is claimed by Band members, that were the teachers have quarrelled with the parents, they do not give the children a fair chance—for the above reason it makes it that much harder to keep the children attending school regularly. I would consider that the above two teachers are either directly or indirectly the cause of more petty disturbance on the Reserve than any other element that I know of. They have the Church divided against itself, and keep individuals and families continually at enmity with each other.

Although the Department asked Mrs. MacPherson to dispose of her goat sometime ago, it is still in the schoolyard. They did send it away for a few weeks, but it was not long until it was back in the schoolyard again. While they keep it tied on a long rope most of the time, the parents still have the same complaints that they previously had in respect to the goat.
Under the above circumstances, I feel that we might get better results, and a fuller cooperation for all concerned, with a change of teachers at No. I School, I quite probably think both Mrs. MacPherson and Mrs. MacDougall would secure better results at a new school where they would have the goodwill of all parents at least to begin with.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of Sept. 12th, I beg to state that I feel it is a direct insult to the teaching ability and daily life of the teachers in No. 1 Indian Day School.

To the best of our knowledge and ability, all the statements therein contained are direct falsehoods. The statement that school is opened and closed at unusual hours and holidays taken without authority cannot be substantiated. This school is always opened at 9 a.m. and closed at 4 p.m., except when we teach till 5 p.m. during the spring term to help prepare the Entrance candidates.
There used to be some discussion regarding school being called at 1:30 p.m. rather than 1 p.m. But when I came here to teach in March 1922 Mr. Roy Abraham told me to call school at 1:30 p.m. partly because the teachers who must live in residence have their own lunch to prepare and partly because the majority of the children attending this school, including the white children of the officials, go home at noon then for lunch and cannot return till 1:30 p.m. To date this order has never been rescinded.

There have never been any holidays taken without authority. On the very rare occasions, when school has been closed, the Agent's permission has always first been obtained. This can be verified from the "School Registers," always inspected by the Public School Inspector, Mr. Down of Sarnia and more recently, under the new regime, twice a month by you.
Indian agent Mr. A. Highfield. He has always told us he has found the reports perfectly satisfactory.

You have been misinformed as not having the general support of the parents on this Reservation. The attendance at this No.1 Indian Day School has never been better than during the past few years. WALPOLE ISLAND AFFAIRS.

To the Editor of The Globe: In the issue of The Globe of Friday, Oct. 28 there is a reference to conditions on Walpole Island given to the semi-annual meeting of the I.L.U. While the conditions described are not given in the report, the whole tenor of the article gives a bad impression of the island. The very worst condition we have on the island is the persecution of Indians on such as you punish. If such persons would go into industry on the island it would be very much better. They appear to wait to at least an other week before they get a feeling that the gifts sent by the band are not distributed as they would wish. Last year they 25 the English Church with over 300 gifts for the Indians here from bands sent by the government churches, Sunday schools, A.Y.P.A.'s and others. These gifts were carefully made by a committee of Indians selected by the rector.

In a population of nearly 1,000 there are still many cases of poverty, but so soon as they are known they are dealt with. Referring mid news item Oct. 28, Mr. Hirstfield, Indian Agent, Chief Inspector, Mr. Brigham, Customs Officer, and Mrs. Brigham, who are the former, they know nothing of improper conditions spoken of. Nor do I.

Henry Smith,
Parish Church of St. John the Baptist,
Walpole Island.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Walpole Island Agency.

There are two day schools on this reserve. I had numerous complaints made to me regarding the teachers at No. 1 school. These were chiefly in regard to irregular school hours, absence from school during noon hour and discrimination against some of the pupils. I understand these complaints have already reached the Department through other sources. It will, therefore, be unnecessary for me to go into detail. I may say, however, that the general attitude of the Indians towards Mrs. McPherson and Mrs. McDougall is entirely antagonistic and there is no possibility, in so far as I was able to judge, of this being overcome. In my opinion these teachers have lost the respect and confidence of the Indian people which to say the least is unfortunate.

I arrived at the school at 3:30 and found the pupils having recess. They were called into the classroom and gave an exhibition of a drill they are preparing for the Christmas season. What I saw of the classroom work was very good. The pupils were tidy and appeared to be well cared for, and in excellent health. This applies to both classrooms of No. 1 school. There is a Junior Red Cross Society in connection with this school.

It has been pointed out in these articles in The School, that agriculture is a utilitarian subject, and we think should always be taught with this in view, and we believe that no subject on the curriculum lends itself so well to home projects of a practical nature, which really give significance to the work.

Successful farming depends on the following factors:
- Location of farm; accessibility to market.
- Suitability of buildings for kind of agriculture carried on.
- Kind and fertility of soil.
- Tillage, including tillage operations to produce suitable tilth and drainage.
- Improved live stock by selection and breeding.
- Selection of seed grain.
- Judicious use of fertilizers.
- Control of plant diseases and insect pests.
- Control of weeds.
- Suitability of type of farming undertaken.
- Rotation of crops.
- Size of farm, machinery, and horsepower.
- Judicious marketing.

Most of the foregoing topics have been dealt with in previous issues of The School. Except for one or two of them they give a wide scope for home projects to supplement the work done in the class.

A PET PARK

There is never a bell rung that Sammie does not answer. He comes running across the fields to march in with the pupils and usually sleeps at the back of the classroom until dismissal bell. Sometimes he follows a class to the floor, waits till they return to their seats and then marches back to his own place. He has learned many tricks due to the patient teaching of his little playmates and is a most useful model in all drawing classes. He will hold any pose until told he may relax and likes nothing better than to sit on a chair in the front of the classroom while the children "draw" him. He goes hunting with the boys on Saturday; serves as a patient for bandaging and first aid work, while with the other dog—a police pup "Peter"—he has been trained to pull the sleighs for the children. What merry races have been run off this winter, each dog having a cheering crowd of little "rooters" to urge him on to victory!

Billie, the goat, was given to the school as a mascot when a mere kid. The children raised him on a bottle. As regularly as intermissions came he would come to the door calling "mahl mahl!" The children took turns feeding him. He afforded no end of fun when taught to pull sleighs and what jolly times all had while he learned. He has "butted" many a snow fort to pieces and eaten many things of value to small owners. Finally he had to be kept tethered to the fence but that did not prevent ambitious little gentlemen from "riding the goat." In the summer he rests. All vacation, he is locked in the school yard where he keeps the grass cut as short as if it had been cut by a lawn-mower. He is most effectual in scaring away would-be picnickers and other trespassers.

The white mice were special friends with the girls who trained them to lie under their middy collars or run into their pockets. In this school, many of the children cannot speak English. I have seen little beginners quite forget their shyness and strangeness when given the school kitty or a baby rabbit to cuddle. Every small person becomes quite friendly when talking of a pet animal.

All our pets are accustomed to being brought into the classroom for nature study lessons, for art models or for geography and they add real interest to these lessons.

Through these pets our pupils learn kindness to animals, responsibility as to their feeding and housing requirements and above all a love for dumb animals, a love that will stay with them all their lives.

For several years, the outdoor activities at our school have centered around a collection of pets who live at the school. I thought perhaps others would like to hear of our experiment.

First and foremost, ours is an ungraded school—two teachers—of about 60 or 85 pupils. Our pets consist of a Billy goat, a family of rabbits, a white rat, two dogs, a cat and a family of guinea pigs. There was also a rooster, Tommy, who recently died of old age. Yes, they all belong to the school, live in the shed in boxes constructed by the pupils who take turns looking after them.

During the summer, they run at large around the playground. They are fed from scraps left after the children's lunches or from collections brought from home and the pride all the pupils take in them is wonderful. Wouldn't you like to hear more of them and their uses?

Sammie, a shepherd-collie comes first by virtue of his age. He is seven years old and came to the school as a puppy—a gift to a little girl.
stem after haying but when not easy to break it. As man cultivates the field, the rootstocks are torn in pieces and carried to different parts of the field where they grow. If very tough, they could not be separated and spread so easily. If very brittle they would break into small pieces and not be carried so far by animals or machinery. Notice the size of the rootstock. Within it there is stored considerable food which nourishes the cutting until it is established as a new plant. The leaves are rather prominently ribbed and quite hairy below, and, like the stems, they are coarse and not relished by live stock. Of course this is an advantage to the plant because it is not disturbed very much. At the top of the stem appear the flowers. How are they arranged on the stem? These are very unattractive in colour and structure and do not produce perfume. Like many other flowers they are cross-pollinated by wind and do not need to attract insects, but they produce abundance of pollen on their long stamens because the wind wastes so much. If we examine the heads or spikes late in the summer, we shall see the numerous seeds which are rather long and slender. This seed is distributed chiefly as an impurity in coarse grass seed but also by farm machinery, by water and to some extent by wind. Couch grass is propagated much more slowly by seed than by rootstock division, but the seeds as a rule are carried much farther and, therefore, have an important place in spreading the plant.

Capacity Assembly
At O.S.B. Concert

Miss Ethel Charlton Presented Memorial Scholarship - Varied Program Heartily Applauded

The June concert of the Ontario School for the Blind attracted an audience that taxed the auditorium to its utmost. The varied program of work, musical, dramatic and physical, was much enjoyed and each and every number won well merited applause. Mr. W. B. Race, principal of the school, occupied the chair and conducted the programme while all assembled. A notable feature of the program was the presentation of the Ethel Charlton scholarship by Miss Ethel Charlton, twin daughter of the Hon. W. A. Charlton, former Premier of Ontario and former speaker of the Ontario House, and Mrs. Charlton, on whose behalf the presentation was made. Miss Ethel Charlton was a former pupil of the school. A brave array of silver trophies was presented to the respective winners by Mr. W. B. Race, who pointed out that the school curriculum was not concentrated upon any one phase of work but was after all but varied. Miss Charlton expressed her pleasure at being present and coming to the concert so well. She then presented the scholarship on behalf of her mother.

VARIED PROGRAM

The program was a revelation to those who attended an O.S.B. concert for the first time. The variety and scope of the work accomplished by the pupils under the masterful instruction appeared exhaustless and reflected great credit upon the members of the school staff. The physical work under Major S. C. Geer, which has won such wide acclaim, was outstanding and pupils in the living pyramid building, general mat work, tumbling, handsprings, headstands and somersaults held the close attention of the large audience throughout and won the hearty applause.

The program opened with a one-act play beautifully staged and comical, "The Clown of Doodle Dock" in which Miss Draper's juniors earned the plaudits of the audience from the outset. The parts were filled with the spoken word and music and the enunciation was excellent. The costumes were cleverly designed by Miss Vera Kellett. The part songs displayed fine expression and modulation and were most creditably sung: "My Bonnie Lass," German; "In Twilight Hour," Horne, and "I Know a Grove," Stafford. The solo of the class piano salon, "Liebestraum," by Ella Koch and "Un Souvenir," Listz and "The Butterfly," Laval, by Grace Leaper, were exceptionally well interpreted. Surely of touch and technique were not lacking. Mrs. George Fairlie in her Bach's "Prelude and Fugue" scored great applause. Howard Shaw sang "Captain Mac," Sanderson. In fine spirit and responded to a vociferous encore with "The Road to Mandalay" which was equally well appreciated. A tender trio of youthful pupils vied in friendly rivalry in their recitations which were inimitably given, as follows: "Grandma's prayer," Helen Self; "A Mortifying Mistake," Leola McWalter; "Little Dutch Angel," Mildred Philips. The senior dramatic endeavor to achieve an all-round education. Many of the honors were won by pupils of the Canadian west and will be proudly taken back to their respective cities as a token of their hard work. Champion, Peter Ryan; senior boy champion, Peter Ryan; senior girl champion, Grace Lewis; intermediate boy champion, Burton James; intermediate girl champion, Edna Reid; junior boy champion, Joseph Brown; junior girl champion, Gwendolen Askett; boy's efficiency trophy (for physical education, hygiene and conduct), David Inglis; girl's general proficiency, Mary Edwards.

Miss Ethel Charlton, in a very charming manner, presented Miss Mary Edwards with the Ethel Charlton Memorial prize, saying that it was given in memory of one who, although physically handicapped, nevertheless had considered thought for others and felt that there was always a law of compensation somewhere at work and that there were others who needed their inspiration and courage. Blindness work was exemplified by Miss Ethel Charlton's reading; "Wreck of the Planter" was given with a musical accompaniment and in unusually good French Canadian patois. Miss Betty Gold gave a most musical rendering of "Polonaise" and "Dance of the Nymphs," charming violin solos which were well played. The concert will be repeated this evening.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. KIRKBY,

Pursuant to telephone conversation with Mr. Burkard, concerning Mrs. H. Macpherson, former teacher of the Walpole Island Indian Day School, I wish to report that she has been employed for a total of 7 years. Complaints and difficulties, which have arisen during her incumbency, indicate that she is hardly suitable for a post on an Indian reserve, particularly when there are missionaries and other white people interested in the same Indians.

Mrs. Macpherson has shown a penchant for interfering in all reserve matters and will not confine her attention to the classroom activities, where she has been quite successful. She has been accustomed to close school at unusual hours, without authority, to attend fairs, picnics, court trials, inquests, etc. She would evince a lively interest in any matters affecting the Indians, even when entirely unconnected with school activity. As a result, the parents were divided in their allegiance.

In 1924, while Mrs. Macpherson was junior teacher, the senior teacher resigned, largely because they could not get along together. In 1925, the Department's Agricultural Representative tried to settle a dispute between Mrs. Macpherson and one of the Indians. Our officer's report reads in part as follows: "So (the agricultural representative and Indian agent) therefore brought the father and boy over to the school. The boy agreed to behave himself in the future and the father agreed to assist the teachers as much as possible. . . . When Walker Bandis and his son were leaving, the teachers (Mrs. Macpherson and her mother) subjected him to considerable abuse, calling him a real bird and a number of other terms, to which he objected. The father then said he did not think it would be any use sending the boy back if the teacher maintained that attitude." At that time, the Department wrote to Mrs. Macpherson in part as follows: "I believe you would be well advised to pay less attention to matters which are not definitely connected with your work among the children of the reserve."

In 1926, it was necessary to write Mrs. Macpherson as follows: "I have your letter of the 11th
instant, regarding the advisability of testifying at a police court case, which follows an incident on the Walpole Island Indian reserve. The Department is satisfied that teachers of Indian day schools should keep out of local difficulties as far as possible."

In January of 1929, the Indian Agent reported in part as follows: "Several times I have noticed the school closed when it should be open . . . . school hours being very irregular."

In July, 1929, the Indian Agent reported in part as follows: "I believe Mrs. Macpherson quite well qualified to teach any school if she would attend strictly to her duties, but I have been unable to get her to keep school at anything like full time. One is liable to see children in the yard, playing, at any time of the day. . . . . Both teachers at this school have been known to close school from a day to three days at a time to go to a fair or picnic. . . . . Neither the classrooms, the residence or the yard or outbuildings are kept very neat or attractive. Owing to the peculiar temperament and disposition of both Mrs. Macpherson and Mrs. Macdonald, they have become very much disliked by the majority of residents on the Reserve, and it is just under threats of taking action under Section 10 of the Indian Act that we have been able to keep a number of the children at school at all. As it is claimed by Band members that where the teachers have quarrelled with the parents they do not give the children a fair chance -- for the above reason it makes it that much harder to keep the children attending school regularly. I would consider that the above two teachers are either directly or indirectly the cause of more petty disturbance on the Reserve than any other element that I know of. They have the children divided against itself and keep individuals and families continually at enmity with each other. Although the Department asked Mrs. Macpherson to dispose of her goat some time ago, it is still in the schoolyard." . . . . "Under the above circumstances, I feel that we might get better results and a fuller cooperation for all concerned, with a change of teachers at No. 1 School, and quite probably both Mrs. Macpherson and Mrs. Macdonald would secure better results at a new school where they would have the goodwill of all parents at least to begin with."

Following this report from the Indian Agent and reports from other Department officers who visited the Reserve, it was decided that there must be a marked improvement if their services were to be retained. The teachers were written to this effect in September last. I may say that petitions for and against Mrs. Macpherson and her mother have since been received, from Indians, by the Department. The Inspector of Indian Agencies, who visited the reserve in December, reported in part as follows: "I had numerous complaints made to me regarding the teachers. These were chiefly in regard to irregular school hours, absence from school during noon hour and discrimination against some of the pupils. . . . I may say that the general attitude of the Indians towards them
is entirely antagonistic and there is no possibility in so far as I was able to judge of this being overcome."

Pursuant to a report and request from the office of the Honourable Mr. Stewart, these teachers were dismissed in June, last.

Deputy Superintendent General.
R.F. Ferrier B.A.,
Supt. Dept. of Education,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

When Mr. Mackenzie was here this summer he told me if I ever got into any difficulties in regard to the school to consult you about it. Well, I am in difficulties and of a nature that even a teacher cannot cope with. It seems that the former teachers are instigating a propaganda among the Indians which is bearing fruit among the parents. I have had two complaints about my methods of punishment and in trying to reason with these people find they don't want the children punished in any way. And to make matters more perplexing I get reminded that the other teachers didn't do that.

These teachers are on the Island nearly every day and the truant officer Mr. Wright tells me he has heard they are telling the parents not to send their children. Of course, Mr. Ferrier, this is all being done without any actual proof but it
It certainly very annoying.

I have found the school advanced two and three classes further than they should be and I am told by the inspector, Mr. Conn, that this is usual in all Indian schools. Would you advise me to keep on feeding the children and parents this delusion?

I gave the children in all the senior classes from the Sr. III to Sr. V the letters capital and small, written and printed, and only one pupil got them right.

The pupils are up well in reading and talk as fluently as white people but surely they are to be taught more than this.

The agent Mr. Highfield has been very helpful but I feel he cannot understand the situation having had no experience in educational matters.

I hope, sir, you will pardon me for unloading my burdens on you but I surely feel I need help if I am to retain my temper and my school.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

Mrs. Daley and I are having considerable difficulty here due according to certain of the Indians, to severe punishment which we have given to their children. The objection however has not been to the harshness of the punishment but rather to the punishment in any amount shape or form.

The family most active in the complaint has a habit of complaining about any and everything and has taken their children from this school before and sent them to a school on the mainland, where they were put out because of unclear heads.

When I first came here, I felt we stepped into a school far beyond behind standard in the knowledge they should have known since then Mrs. Daley and myself have worked hard to bring them to the efficiency necessary for the classes they were then in. In order to do
this as quick a time as possible we have had to detain after four certain lazy, careless or slow learning children and quite frequently at first to administer Corporal punishment. The chief objection was raised last winter when I kept two boys in till around half past five in order to get them up with their classes, at half past six the parents called me asking why their children were not home. I have witnesses to prove those boys were skating on the river till nearly half past five but still their parents blamed me. Then on the second of March I had trouble again with one of the same boys and from the third until the thirteenth he stayed at home, the parents refusing to send him until they took it before the Indian Council here on Walpole Island. But before this time came the agent got us together and the boy started to school on the thirteenth of March.

Last week I received a complaint that this same boy had vermin and in the checking over I gave personally I found four in the school with vermin, two of them being his brothers following Dr Rowland's advice (the Island Doctor) and getting permission from the Agent, Mr Highfield, I sent all four home to get cleaned up since then a
person friend of theirs has lodged a complaint with Mrs. Daley about keeping his boy of whom this guardian is after four and using very insulting language to her over the telephone. The telephone has been used frequently also by the other family to find fault with our methods of running this school.

The family most to blame is Joe Sands' and Mr. Ferrier, what I want to know is are we doing wrong in keeping these children in after four and in punishing with a strap for continued tardiness or are we in the right? If we are right then I wish to goodness that your department would stop this bother and annoyance which we are subjected to.

Hoping to hear from you soon on this matter.

Remain sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to trouble Mrs. Daley and yourself have encountered at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School. It is difficult for one who is not in close touch with the situation to prescribe a course of action in connection with the discipline at a school. After all, discipline is a matter of personal equation. I believe you would be well advised to enlist the cooperation of Mr. Indian Agent Highfield.

At Indian schools generally, teachers will find a peculiar situation in connection with discipline. Indian parents are not in the habit of administering corporal punishment and, on the whole, they dislike it when used in schools. On the other hand, if teachers are fair and just, there is not often trouble from fathers and mothers. When you do receive complaints or are disturbed by parents, I believe it advisable to inform the Indian agent. He knows the particular father or mother and the home conditions. He can then advise you as to what action to pursue.

Generally speaking, I would not administer corporal punishment for continued tardiness. I would reserve it for real extremities. Be patient and deal with your problems thoughtfully and quietly.

The Department understands that you may have special difficulty with certain parents. Do not argue with them. Refer them to the Indian agent and do the best you can at your school.

Dear Sir:

On Saturday the twenty-fourth of October I received a complaint from a white family — that their children had got very thin there at school. I examined both rooms and found from thirty children existed with three rooms. It was impossible to send so large a number home and they could not be certain that they would be cleaned. we have had a week or a note from the parents stating their child has had a bath but I am not sure they haven't seen water below the collar for over months.

MEMORANDUM:  
Ottawa, April 17th, 1939.

Doctor McGill

With reference to your memorandum of the 7th February, last, it has been decided to appoint Mr. James Daly, School Teacher at Walpole Island Indian Agency, as Acting Indian Agent, Grade 3, during the illness of Mr. A.C.W. Highfield.

Mr. Daly should continue to occupy his present quarters in the schoolhouse, as it is understood his wife is the other School Teacher. He will, of course, not receive any allowances for house, fuel or light while acting as Agent and occupying his present residence. Mr. Daly, who is not a returned soldier is to be definitely advised that, should Mr. Highfield be retired owing to ill health, no assurance can be given that he will receive the appointment of Agent. He should be fully informed regarding the returned soldier preference given in accordance with the Civil Service Act and Regulations.

Mrs. Morgan Dalgetty, of Port Lampton, is to be appointed as Teacher to replace Mr. Daly. Her employment is to be continued only until the end of the present school term. She will not live in the schoolhouse. Before her marriage she was a Teacher in the same school.

The above change should be made effective on the 24th instant, or, if this is not practical, on the 1st May, 1939, as it is essential that someone be in charge of the Reserve when the Spring opens up and seeding commences.

A requisition should be prepared for the temporary appointment of an Indian Agent, Grade 3, for a period of three months, during the absence of Mr. Highfield on account of illness. A reference to Treasury Board should also be prepared recommending the establishment of the temporary position during the illness of Mr. Highfield.

Dear Doctor Christie:

I have now acknowledged your letter of September 8, written by you on behalf of Mrs. R. J. Ross, who has recently been appointed by the Department to the principalship of the Walpole Island Indian Day School. The Minister is at present absent from Ottawa and is not likely to return for several days.

I have discussed the subject matter of your communication with the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch. These officials feel that some misunderstanding appears to exist in respect to the appointment of Mrs. Ross to the Walpole Island School. The records in the Department indicate that the Reverend R. J. Ross retired from the principalship of the Round Lake Indian Residential School early in the year 1935. Immediately following his resignation he was re-appointed by the Home Mission Board of the United Church to a mission station at Moraviantown, Ontario. Mrs. Ross at that time was nominated for the position of day school teacher at the Moraviantown Indian Day School. It was pointed out, however, to the United Church authorities at that time that married women were not eligible for such appointments under the then existing regulations. In view of the fact, however, that Mrs. Ross was particularly well qualified to undertake instruction at the school, and in response to the representations made to us by the United Church, we appointed her to the position, in violation of our own regulations.

The Department was notified by the Reverend Dr. Dorsey, on behalf of the Home Mission Board of the

Dr. H. E. Christie,
Supervisor of Medical Services,
Dept. of National War Services,
Ottawa.
United Church, on June 14, 1941, that the Reverend R. J. Ross had died in May, and in the same letter the church authorities nominated F. J. Dodson to take charge of the Indian school and to act as missionary on the Moraviantown reserve. This decision on the part of the church authorities meant that Mrs. Ross was compelled to retire from the position of teacher at the Moraviantown school at the end of the academic year 1941. The Department, in a letter to the Reverend Dr. Dorsey dated June 16, 1941, intimated to the United Church that inasmuch as Mrs. Ross' services had been satisfactory, we were prepared to nominate her for the principaship of the Indian school at Walpole Island, provided that it was not the intention of the United Church authorities to nominate her for a school operated by the Department in co-operation with them. Dr. Dorsey, in his reply dated June 17, 1941, stated:

"I note what you say about Mrs. Ross. I may say that Mrs. Lovers, of the Woman's Missionary Society, has asked Mrs. Ross if she would accept nomination by us, but so far she has not seen her way clear to do so. Consequently, if you desire to communicate with her regarding the vacancy at Walpole Island, I think you should be free to do so. She can then make up her mind as to which position she will accept, as I know she has received a suggestion from the Woman's Missionary Society.

Immediately following the receipt of this information, Mrs. Ross was appointed to the Walpole Island School. This is a two-room school. Mrs. Ross will receive $80.00 per month and, in addition, free furnished quarters, fuel, light, etc. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch are not aware of any other school in the Dominion where conditions would be more congenial for Mrs. Ross than at Walpole Island. In addition to the accessibility of the island, she will have -
have the constant companionship of an associate teacher. In making this appointment the officials of the Department were prompted almost solely by personal considerations for Mrs. Ross. This school was in their judgment the best school available this year.

You can readily appreciate that it is somewhat difficult to give the full history of this particular appointment in a letter at this time. The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch would feel deeply indebted to you if you could find it convenient to call at the office of the Superintendent of Welfare and Training at any time and pursue the correspondence in respect to the employment of Mrs. Ross by the Department - first at Moraviantown and then at Valpole Island.

Indian day school teachers are classified as temporary Civil Servants. They do not contribute to the Superannuation Fund and are not eligible for superannuation allowances. The superannuation to which you refer is no doubt superannuation allowance for which provision has been made by the United Church.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am writing you about the situation at No. 1 school for the coming year. I had written Mr. Arneil regarding the same but understand that he is away at present.

Frankly we do not want Mrs. Ross back as teacher if it can be avoided. This is possibly a great deal of selfishness on our part but we feel that we do not care to have our own boy soured on school life and this feeling is also true of Mr. & Mrs. Bachus the Customs officer on the Reserve. In all fairness to Mrs. Ross I believe her to be a good teacher but feel that she came here at the wrong time. Her husband had died shortly before she came, she had her heart set on a school I believe on Lanesey or some other Reserve and as a result there wasn't anything right about Walpole Island or the school. Our Indians are much more stupid than other Indians (in her opinion) and as a result this attitude has been carried into the school room. It got to such a state that one of my most sensible Councillors stated in council that if things didn't improve that he would not send his children to school even if we put him in jail. Mrs. Ross was well liked and highly respected on Moraviantown Reserve as a teacher and it seems a pity that an exchange with some other teacher could not be made.

The Bachuses and we do not feel that we can afford to send our children to a school on the mainland but we will have to do so if things happen which we foresee will happen. Mrs. Bachus mentioned about her little boy being of a nervous disposition and Mrs. Ross answered her that when she gets to teaching him she would take the nervousness out of him.

Mrs. Taylor teacher in the Junior room last year is very efficient and on top of that has natural ability to understand children. Her husband has but recently been operated on for cancer of the bowel. She could come back when school starts if she were in charge of the residence and could bring him with her.

Payment from June 7 to June 30 inclusive
