Morley McCracken from Sarnia called this morning by phone and informed me that you were trying to get me by phone yesterday. I was not in the office a great deal of the time yesterday but Mrs. Daley was at home and should have heard any calls here.

About the school situation on the Reserve No 2 school is in charge of Mrs. Ethel George and it is her desire to stay. You are aware of her qualifications and I believe that her report from the Inspector is fair.

At No 1 we have Mrs. Maude Dalgetty in charge, part of the past academic year she taught the Junior room, and part of the year the Senior room after Mr. Marshal was relieved by Myrtle Williams, Indian, of this Reserve.

There would appear to have been misunderstanding about Mr. Marshal giving up the school. I understand that he said that he would take the senior room until another teacher could be procured; he now insists that he said that he would keep the room until another qualified teacher could be procured. Myrtle Williams was talking to Mrs. Dalgetty and told her she would like to take the junior room and it was agreed that if she would come to the room and work under Mrs. Dalgetty for a week or so and if she was then able to carry on, Mrs. Dalgetty would recommend her to this office. Mrs. Dalgetty was satisfied that Myrtle could do the work and under that recommendation, I recommended her to you. Her subsequent good work has justified that recommendation. The new school inspector has stated that she is doing the work all right but that she is using the older methods.

Mr. Marshal was here sometime ago and stated that he thought that the teachers of the school should be mission workers and that they would be a great help to him in his work; I appreciate his reasoning and if all things were equal I would
favour his plan but we have a qualified teacher in charge of the school, and we have an Indian girl doing a reasonably good job teaching the Junior room; the teachers get along well together, there is no question about the living quarters, I certainly am not in favour of a change.

Frankly, I am not in favour of the church interfering with the day schools anyway, if ministers wish to enter the schools to teach their particular tribe that is fine but as the Department does the paying, the churches should stay out of the management. I have every respect for Mr. Marshal and did appreciate him stepping in when he was sorely needed, but now other teachers are there and I feel that he should run his church and the teachers, and the Dept. run the school.

I hope that you do not think I am being too blunt in this matter.

James W. Daley

The Indian Agent informs me that he does not intend advertising for teachers; this is a two-roomed school with a small teacherage for the two teachers. Last summer the agent did nothing to secure teachers and in September the school was unable to open.

The agent is interested financially in the Algoma-Walpole Ferry service, operated by his life long friend Mr. M. Dalgety. Mrs. Dalgety is a school teacher. Last year the Dalgetys were in a sad plight because they had to vacate the house they rented on Walpole Island and nothing else suitable offered. The agent then arranged for Mrs. Dalgety to take the No. 1 School, and the family (5) occupied the teacherage.

I was asked to teach, and agreed to take the senior room until a teacher could be secured. Later the agent arranged for an Indian girl with only one year's high school (gained whilst an inmate of an American Home of Correction) to take charge of the Junior room, as Mrs. Dalgety asked for the senior grades and I was unwilling to take them.

Now the position is that the teacherage is occupied by the Dalgety family so that a second teacher could not possibly be accommodated, and the Indian people feel that the arrangement was merely one to suit the Dalgetys and the agent whom they claim is a sleeping partner in the ferry business.

It should be noted that this year under my tuition the first pupil to qualify for High School passed, the first pupil in a number of years. This is not a church controlled school - it used to be, and in those days we graduated Grade VIII pupils regularly and sent one or two to University. I do not feel that the criticism of church operated schools is justified - and it is encouraged by the Indian Department officials because they want full control themselves. When we have Christian teachers, or missionaries serving a principal, we have people interested in the Indians, not teaching for a job.

On Walpole Island, as an example of a Departmentally run school, we have had only one real certificated teacher since the Department took over from the church. We need teachers who are interested in the moral and physical training, and these are best assured by securing missionary hearted people.
No. 2 School, Walpole Island

This is a one roomed school with a native teacher whom the Indians do not regard very highly. She is a married woman who was living apart from her husband, but I believe the husband has now died. I am concerned at the fact that the pupils never get beyond Grade VI, and the conditions around this school are notoriously immoral.

Rev. A. R. Marshall,

With reference to the letter received by you from Mr. W. Bryce, Member of Parliament for Selkirk, I am referring only to those sections of his letter which deal with the teachers and schools.

1. Mrs. Maude Dalgety - Senior Room Walpole Island No. 1 Day School.

The Inspector's report on this school is dated June 25, 1946 and is signed by Mr. J.L. Barrett, Inspector of Schools for the Province of Ontario. Mrs. Dalgety has a Permanent First Class Certificate and has had eleven and a half years teaching experience with two and a half years in Indian schools. She taught last term at U.S. No. 16 in Chatham Township.

The Inspector rates this teacher as follows:
A (excellent) for Appearance, Health, Personality, Initiative, Discipline, Relations, and Management. B (good) for Teaching skill, Preparations, Language, Community Service and Pupils' progress.

Under General Comments Mr. Barrett says:
"Mrs. Dalgety is a competent teacher and the work in general is good. A splendid craft programme is being carried on."

Conclusion:

In view of the above report I notified the Indian Agent on July 12th, that the services of Mrs. Dalgety should be retained in her present position.

2. Miss Muriel Williams - Junior Room Walpole Island No. 1 Day School.

The Inspector's report on this school is dated June 25, 1946 and is signed by Mr. J.L. Barrett, Inspector of Schools for the Province of Ontario. Miss Williams has no professional certificate and no previous teaching experience.

The Inspector rates this teacher as follows:
B (good) for Appearance, Health, Initiative, Relations and Community Service and C (fair) for Personality, Discipline, Management, Teaching Skill, Preparations, Language and Pupils' Progress.
Under General Comments, Mr. Barrett writes:

"Miss Williams is doing fair work for an inexperienced and unqualified teacher. She has profited by the help Mrs. Dalgety has given but she definitely needs professional training. It is only natural that she should teach as she was taught and, in consequence her methods are somewhat outdated. However, she is drilling on the fundamentals to such an extent that the children are leaving her room knowing a fair amount of factual material. The size of the class would present a real challenge to an experienced teacher and it is to Miss Williams' credit that she is doing as well as she is."

Conclusion:

After reading the above report, I wrote as follows to the Indian Agent on July 12th:

"I note your report regarding Miss Myrtle Williams. While you state she has done reasonably good work, at the same time it must be realized that she is not a qualified teacher.

Do you consider that it would be possible to secure a qualified teacher to replace her? Please give this matter your immediate attention and let me have an early reply.

As yet I have received no reply to this letter.

3. Mrs. Ethel George - Walpole Island No. 2 Day School.

The Inspector's report on this school is dated June 24, 1946 and is signed by Mr. F.L. Barrett, Inspector of Schools for the Province of Ontario. Mrs. George has no professional teaching certificate but she has been teaching for some forty-four years with twenty-two years in Indian schools.

Note: (She was first appointed as teacher of the Kettle Point School in the Sarnia Agency on January 1, 1907. She was transferred from that school to the Walpole Island School on January 1, 1924).

The Inspector rates this teacher as follows:
B (Good) on practically the entire scale.

Under General Comments Mr. Barrett writes:

"On the whole the pupils are making fair progress. Many, however do not begin school soon enough and, hence, are over-age for their grade. More Manual Training would seem advisable in order to create an interest in school and help those not academically inclined. Additional copies of the "Dick and Jane" readers are needed. The teacher is to be complimented upon the neat and attractive appearance of the grounds".

Conclusion:

In view of the great shortage of certificated teachers and Mrs. George's long and satisfactory experience I wrote to the Indian Agent on July 12th and told him that the services of Mrs. George should be retained for the academic year 1946-47."
General Comments:

I have this day wired Mr. Phelan in care of the Indian Agent at Sarnia to proceed to Walpole Island and there to interview both Indian Agent Dalby and Reverend Mr. Marshall. I feel that there can be no complaint about the services of either Mrs. Dalby or Rev. George. We have already indicated to the Agent that he should replace Miss Williams with a certificated teacher. Insofar as the teachings being used by the Dalby family, I would prefer withholding comment on this until hearing from Mr. Phelan.

Memorandum:

Colonel Neary,
Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

On receipt of your telephone message to me in Sarnia on July 25th regarding the letter received by Mr. W. Bryce from Reverend A.E. Marshall, Indian Missionary, Walpole Island, Ontario, I immediately phoned the latter and arranged to see him at ten thirty A.M. Friday, July 26th.

I met him at the time mentioned above and had an interview with him lasting one hour.

...POLE ISLAND No. 1 School.

During the academic year 1945-46 this school was in charge of Mrs. Delgetty as Principal and Miss Myrtle Williams as Assistant. The former is a fully qualified teacher but the latter who is an Indian girl has no professional qualifications.

When Mrs. Delgetty was appointed in September, 1945, the Indian Agent did not advise this Branch that the teacher, her husband and three children would occupy the teacher's living quarters at the No. 1 School. As a result, when the second teacher was secured it was necessary to obtain someone who would not live in the teacher's quarters as their would be no accommodation for another person in view of the fact that the quarters were being occupied by a family of five.

Never Mr. Marshall admitted that Mrs. Delgetty was a good teacher but took exception to the situation that has existed with regard to the living quarters and also to the employment of an unqualified teacher as assistant.

Mr. Marshall who is an Anglican Missionary of the Walpole Island Reserve has held that position for the past year and appears to be extremely interested not only in the education of the Indian children but in their general social welfare. He expressed the opinion that if we could secure a man and his wife to take charge of this school, it would be the ideal situation. I agreed with him but pointed out that it was difficult to secure such teachers. He admitted that he did not know of such a couple at the present time but that it might be possible to secure such a couple in the future.

For the academic year 1946-47, he felt that it would be desirable to appoint two female teachers who would not only carry on the school in a capable manner but would give him some assistance in organizing boy scouts, girl guides, etc., and thus improve the general situation on the Reserve. In view of the difficulty we have experienced in obtaining teachers these past few years, I told Mr. Marshall that we were not aware of any two qualified female teachers. He expressed the opinion that he could secure them. I told him that if he could do so, he should let us know early in August and that I felt certain that the Department would approve of such appointments. Reverend Mr. Marshall intends to be present at an Anglican conference at Bayfield, Ontario, during the current week and I promised him that a letter would be written to him authorizing him to secure if possible two qualified female teachers for the coming academic year.
The Indian Agent appears to regard the services of Mrs. Dalgetty very highly and did not see any reason against allowing herself and family to occupy the living quarters at the No. 1 School. He also expressed the opinion that the Indian girl who served as assistant had done fairly well.

I believe that Reverend Mr. Marshall can secure two qualified female teachers and that they would work in conjunction with him and that such co-operation would be beneficial to all the Indian children in the vicinity of the No. 1 School.

**WILLOE ISLAND NO. 2 School.**

Reverend Mr. Marshall's letter to Mr. Bryce regarding this school reads as follows:

"This is a one roomed school with a native teacher whom the Indians do not regard very highly. She is a married woman who was living apart from her husband, but I believe the husband has now died. I am concerned at the fact that the pupils never got beyond Grade VI and the conditions around this school are notoriously immoral."

In discussing this paragraph with Mr. Marshall he agreed that the immoral conditions which he mentioned are not due to the employment of Mrs. George. I pointed out to him that she had been in our employ for many years and that the reports received from the Provincial School Inspector were always reasonably satisfactory. The fact that few of the pupils went beyond grade six was likely due in part at least to the apathy on the part of the parents. He agreed that such was a fair presentation of the situation. As Mr. Marshall stated that Mrs. George was still extremely active he withdrew any opposition he might have had towards her continued employment for the academic year 1946-47. I informed Mr. Marshall that we would write to Mrs. George and direct her to co-operate to the fullest possible extent with Mr. Marshall in organizing Boy Scouts, Girl Guides, etc., so as to improve conditions among the younger Indians living in the immediate vicinity of the No. 2 School.

Reverend Mr. Marshall appears to be a very reasonable man and is anxious to do everything possible for the Indians on the Willoe Island Reserve. He appreciated the fact that Mr. Hoey and myself had asked me to interview him.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,

Ottawa, July 29, 1946.

No. 1 School, Walpole Island.

The Indian Agent informs me that he does not intend advertising for teachers. This is a two-roomed school with a small teacherage for the two teachers. Last summer the Agent did nothing to secure teachers and in September the school was unable to open.

The Agent is interested financially in the Walpole Island Ferry service, operated by his life-long friend Mr. H. Dalgety. Mrs. Dalgety is a school teacher. During the Dalgetys were in need of a place because they had to vacate the house they rented on Walpole Island and nothing else suitable offered. The Agent then arranged for Mrs. Dalgety to take the No. 1 School, and the family occupied the teacherage.

I was asked to teach and agreed to take the senior room until a teacher could be secured. Later the Agent arranged for an Indian girl with only one year's high school (gained whilst an inmate of an American Home of Correction) to take charge of the Junior room, as Mrs. Dalgety asked for the senior grades and I was unwilling to take them.

Now the position is that the teacherage is occupied by the Dalgety family so that a second teacher cannot possibly be accommodated, and the Indian people feel that the arrangement was merely one to suit the Dalgetys and the agent whom they claim is a sleeping partner in the ferry business.

It should be noted that this year under my tuition the first pupil to qualify for High School passed, the first pupil in a number of years. This is not a church controlled school—it used to be, and in those days we graduated Grade VIII pupils regularly and sent one or two to university. I do not feel that the criticism of church operated schools is justified—and it is encouraged by the Indian Department officials because they want full control themselves. When we have Christian teachers, or missionaries serving as principal, we have people interested in the Indians, not teaching for a job.

On Walpole Island, as an example of a Departmentally run school, we have had only one real certificated teacher since the Department took over from the church. We need teachers who are interested in the moral and physical training, and these are best assured by securing missionary hearted people.
No. 2 School, Walpole Island.

This is a one roomed school with a native teacher whom the Indians do not regard very highly. She is a married woman who was living apart from her husband, but I believe the husband has now died. I am concerned at the fact that the pupils never got beyond Grade VI and the conditions around this school are not ideally in order.

(Sgd) Rev. A. R. Marshall,

Dear Mr Phelan:

Hearing that Mr Arneil was on the island on Monday and Tuesday I phoned him regarding the teacher vacancy at No I School. I informed Mr Arneil that we (our church Board of Management) had located a teacher prospect whom we wished to nominate, and was somewhat shortly informed by Mr Arneil that he was appointing Mrs Daley, wife of the Indian Agent.

In view of the fact that we do not feel Mr Arneil has the right of appointment in this case and in view of your own most fair and considerate attitude in the matter, I decided after consulting with my Board to go ahead and nominate a Mrs Sharen of Wallaceburg.

Dear Mr Neary:

Thank you for your letter regarding the recent appointment to the vacancy at No I School here. When I phoned Mr Arnell he was then at the Agents' house or office. I informed him that we had a lady in view but he said he had appointed Mrs Daley, and I understood he said he had not yet sent the appointment to Ottawa. When I said we still wished to nominate Mrs Sharen and if necessary I would send to Ottawa, he very shortly said "Do that". I do not feel that the appointment had then been made by Ottawa, and I am asking your re-consideration of same on grounds which I hope to make clear.

I have recently been appointed by the Archbishop to head up our Indian Workers committee, and I believe that this situation at Walpole is a good test case of the ability of church and Dept to co-operate. I am certain that with men like Mr Phelan, or at least the attitude he took when here last year...we should have no difficulty in co-operating for the good of the Indian. I am sorry to say however that the decisions he made seem to have been over ridden, and however much we desire to co-operate we are now conscious that the welfare of the Indian or the church is not very likely to be considered first.

Our denomination has been working for a Century here. We own the allegiance of by far the majority of the people. During the Anglican Advance Movement last year we took a new person to person canvas, and actually discovered that very few families did not either belong to us or look to us as their church for every purpose. There is no other denomination working here. I have an official letter from the United Church giving me their blessing in taking all the people under my wing...and stating that the only block was one or two local Indians headed by Elder Soney who for personal economic reasons wished to retain the United faith. Nor have I restricted myself to our people in my ministry...and rejoice that the few outside my flock are able to claim some Christian allegiance.

Despite the fact that we held the majority of the people and had been here so long...when I took over here two years ago I was asked to build up (or attempt to build) a broken down work. Mr Daley in conversations was not slow to inform me that the reason for the breakdown was that every Minister here no matter what denomination was either a rogue, immoral, or useless. Under the circumstances it did not take me long to appreciate that little real co-operation could have been possible between my predecessors and the Agent. I am in somewhat of a position to claim to know the Indian...can talk a bit of their language, and have given up a lot to work with them. In two years we have made remarkable recovery....but I have been very conscious again and again that where co-operation from the Dept is to be delayed, I am absent. When I mentioned to Mr ARNEILL that Mr Daley was non-co-operative he used much harsher terms...which makes it still more difficult for me to understand how...having such a poor opinion of the Agent would do anything to inflict him upon our work and people any longer than necessary.

Appreciating Mr Arnell's difficulty last Fall I did all I could to co-operate, and even went to the former teacher Mrs Dalgity, and together with Mr Arnell persuaded her to carry on. It was then that Mr Arnell said he would not appoint Mrs Dalgity except for the full scholastic year so that her leaving in January was a surprise. I had nothing against Mrs Dalgity...but she was not in sympathy with our church...and of no help to us. The same is true of Mrs Daley whom I respect...although there will be opposition to the family going back into the teachersage. Mr Phelan thoroughly understood that apart from any rights our denomination might claim under the Act...the work facing us on Walpole demanded all the co-operation and sympathy any of us could give each other. We do not feel we are getting it in this matter, and unless a clean cut decision is made now I do not believe we shall stand much chance of successfully nominating anyone next September.
I think perhaps at one time we need to settle whether we have any moral or legal right under that section of the Indian Act which grants 'majority' denomination the privilege of nominating the teacher? I think too that with two rooms teachers provided here the Dept may well insist that the teaching staff be accommodated there... without having to board a teacher out. In this regard of course the difficult times have to be considered as with the qualifications of the teacher.

I am aware that much of this will be outside the province of your department of Training... except that it might make clear our reasons for heartily desiring that the teachers be missionary hearted and at the least willing to work with us. If anyone could show me one piece of work being carried out on this reservation for the good and welfare of the Indian, outside of the church, I would be surprised. The people can be led but are hard to drive anywhere.... We have just paid for an eleven hundred dollar electric organ... every cent raised by the Indian... on the island!

It is time that we realised that the Indian resents and hates the white man because every white man having official or other business with the Indian has an ulterior motive... and this is just as true I fear of some of us who are missionary workers. I do believe however that when that natural suspicion on the native part is overcome by a man with a sincere desire to promote his welfare... almost miracles can be worked.

You will forgive the lecture which I know you have no need of. I do assure you that I have no restriction upon my desire to fully co-operate, and I might add that in former days I found Mr Hoey most delightfully co-operative.

I shall not commend Kettle Point vacancy to Mrs Sharen as I am vitally interested in Walpole Island and not Kettle Point. I shall ask Mrs Sharen to place her application with you as I believe despite the policy of the Dept not to replace teachers in the middle of term... it has been done here twice in the past year or so... and no doubt can be done again.

Thanking you, and with kind regards

Yours sincerely

Dear Sir;

I have not previously answered your letter of Feb 24th as I have been waiting Mrs Sharen's application. The delay was I understand caused by Mrs Sharen's understandable reluctance to make application whilst Mrs Daley was engaged. I am personally supporting Mrs Sharen in applying for the Principalship of the school on the grounds that with the majority of the people members of our church, and the remainder almost wholly looking to us for ministration, we have under Sect 100 of the Indian Act the right to expect that consideration which the Indian Affairs Branch have ever extended to the churches operating for the welfare of the Indians.

I am not seeking a drawn out discussion in the matter for no good can be served...but I am insisting with all my power and influence upon the right of the church to be interested in the people entrusted with the teaching of the Indian. I would further add that I am not even vitally concerned as to the teachers being members of my denomination providing they are here to do a job of work for the good of the Indian...and willing to give and accept our co-operation. When I arrived here two years ago the Principal was Miss Ross...the widow of an United Church Clergyman........She was certainly not Anglican...but she suited us admirably...was loved by the people and detested by the Agent...so she went.

In Mrs Sharen's case I am glad she is an Anglican...It will save many complications...and if a qualified second teacher cannot be secured she has a lady living with her at Wallaceburg who would suit us excellently, and while not a qualified teacher has had many years experience among children in church work etc.

Yes, Sir I am referring to Section 100 (2).....with five hundred and eighty nine resident Indians on my church membership I see no reason why I should not expect your co-operation. As for the Dept policy of not changing teachers in mid term....it happened last year without necessity...and can happen again I am sure.

I must take exception to your statement that as a result of my representations last Summer...Miss Williams was dismissed. Miss Williams is or was a member of my church...and much bad capital has been made of this untruth. My representations last Summer were made in relation to the whole work of the schools on the island...Mr Daley, himself engaged Miss Williams pledged that it was only for the present term...and himself stated that I could go ahead and find teachers. It was merely because his friend Mrs Dalgity wanted to stay until her house was ready for occupancy...that Mr Daley engaged Miss Williams again...knowing that no teacher would accept the Junior room when the teacherage was occupied by Mr & Mrs Dalgity and three small children...one too young to attend school. Your Mr Phelan had a co-operative and understanding attitude in the matter...and it is my hope that he interpreted rightly your Departmental reaction.
I have stated that I want to avoid controversy. I cannot ask you to replace Mr. Stratton with Mrs. Sharen, although you must do as you wish about that. I want teachers, and especially the teacher handling our pre-confirmation age children (Seniors) to be Anglican, or at least sympathetic towards us. The Junior room teacher is not nearly so important, but here too we would very naturally value a church person.

I think too in view of the progress we are making on the island, and our future plans, we should have your departmental policy in regard to such a situation as Walpole provides, in relation to Section 100(2), because we are not always going to be satisfied with the obvious disregard of the needs of our people by those entrusted with their welfare.

It must be a bad headache for you and your field staff, but I feel with you that there ought to be no difficulty in co-operation between your Dept and my Church.

I might say that I doubt very much that Mrs. Sharen would take the Junior room under Mrs. Daley, who has been out of practice for several years, and has a young family. Mrs. Sharen would have a boy in the Senior room, a girl going to High School at Wallaceburg. I should most certainly suggest Mrs. Sharen as Principal if Mrs. Daley is to continue this term.

Thanking you for the court by

I am

In different places in the past we have had the experience of employing a married teacher whose husband resided in the residence and invariably difficulties have arisen between the husband and the Indians on the reserve.

Dear Sir,

File 442-1E

Although I received your acceptance of my resignation for W.S.I. Walpole Island, I am applying for a teaching position if there happens to be a vacancy in any of the Indian schools in Ontario, for the end of the present term and for the school year beginning in September.

As my resignation stated, I gave it on the advice of Dr. Card, who was advised by the doctor of the X-Ray dept. of Sarnia's St. Joseph's Hospital. Apparently they believed a serious condition might be developing and that I should have the attention of Dr. Burr of the Cancer Clinic Kingston, under whom I had received treatment after an operation in Nov. 1947.

On March 21, Dr. Burr gave me a chest examination and had two more X-Ray plates taken. He said that he could find nothing
wrong and that I was in a good condition in spirit of recently recovering from "flu" and Bronchitis. However he said that he would re-examine all plates and have a consultation with Dr. Boucher who performed the operation and for me to return April 7.

On April 7, Dr. Burs told me that there was no indication of anything serious; a few marks showed on the plates. These were scars on the lung, burnt by the Deep X-Ray treatment. It was these spots, and the severe bronchitis cough that must have influenced the doctors at Sarnia.

When the doctors in Kingston and physicians of Gananoque emphatically tell me that I am able to continue work, and I feel well, I wish to get work as soon as possible.

Trusting you may be able to give me a chance to prove to others as well as to myself that I am capable of giving faithful service,

Yours respectfully,

Susan A. Seal,
Box 552, Gananoque, Ont.

Dear Miss Seal:

I have received your letter of April 12th and am pleased to note that your doctors feel that you are ready to teach again.

We do not have a vacancy in one of our schools at the present time, and I am sorry that I did not hear from you sooner. There was a school on the Gibson Reserve but this was filled over the Easter holidays. However, I shall keep you in mind and will write you again if a suitable vacancy occurs.

I presume that you would not want to go to a school that is too isolated or too far distant from a doctor. Many of our schools are located on Indian reserves which are rather far from civilization.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Bishop Lurton:

I have for answer your letter of July 14 concerning the Reverend Wilfred Murray formerly to come at the above school. Please find attached a self-addressed letter which I sent to the Reverend Mr. Murray on July 14.

When we were advised by Mrs. Bradbury in May of his resignation, we immediately began the search for a replacement. Upon an inspection trip to Calgary in June, I found two qualified and experienced teachers who were friends and who were willing to share the teacher's residence at Algoma Island. Therefore, I immediately wrote arrangements for them to take the intermediate and junior rooms while Miss Smith will of course carry on with the senior room.

Just after I had advised these two teachers of their appointment, I heard from Mrs. Bradbury advising that it was not possible for him to continue to come. As the appointments of these two teachers had been confirmed and they had both made their plans accordingly, I wrote to the Reverend Mr. Murray as indicated above.

I regret sincerely this instance and will do everything possible to employ the Reverend Mr. Bradbury again.
When a vacancy occurs at either of the Walpole Island or Oka schools, we do not hesitate to recruit his services last year and feel that he is a capable teacher.

Miss Roberts and Miss Benson are both capable and qualified teachers with many years of experience in provincial schools. Their work at Oka last year was favourably reported on, and they are both genuinely interested in the improvement of conditions on our Indian reserves. I do hope that their work is satisfactory at Walpole Island and that we can look forward to a year of progress at the school. The Entrance results this year were most satisfactory, and the high school pupils have done well at Wallaceburg.

Dear Col. Neary:

I would appreciate being relieved of the Music Teaching in No. 1 School this year. I have had a very busy year and summer and I would rather not be tied to teaching this fall.

Rooms One and Two were quite enthusiastic about their music last year and made very good progress. Room Three was less enthusiastic, probably because of the lack of encouragement between the regular lessons.

The Junior and Intermediate Rooms sang at the Music Festival in Sarnia last May and received 79 marks in each of two choruses. Our girls' solo made a mark of 78.

The year was finished with a recital in the Parish Hall. The proceeds from a collection at the door, amounting to $17.11, were spent in treats for a school picnic.

All in all, I think the children have made a good start with their music and with their teachers' help will continue to make progress. I enjoyed working with the Indian children and will continue to help them whenever the opportunity arises.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Mrs. Dorothy Stallwood.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask if you could grant me the privilege of receiving an increase in my salary for the next six months. The reason I am doing this is because our family needs extra income at this time due to the support of our children out of work. My husband's father has had a very bad year on the farm and my father-in-law is unemployed. We happen to be the sole support in both cases and it would help us greatly to have ready cash each month.

We also carry heavy insurance which we must keep up.

It does not seem to put the Department to a lot of bother in this matter. Whatever we can do to help, we shall be only too glad to cooperate. We need write at the end of each month if you so desire.

Thank you for past favours in this regard and trust that this request will meet with your approval.

Extract from Inspector's Monthly Report on the No. 1 Walpole Island Day School, dated May 1915.

Buildings and Premises.

Fence at the end of the school grounds was taken down last fall and has not been put up yet.

Class-room 17' x 27' x 10', about 4890 cubic feet. Where there is adequate provision for ventilation there should be 250 cu. ft. of air space per pupil, based on the maximum attendance. On this basis there is air space for 18 pupils and there 32 Indian children and 2 white children present on the occasion of my visit, and there are 57 children who should attend this school.

The class-room has a pine floor but I think it should be oiled. The oil renders the floor more sanitary, inasmuch as it keeps down the dust. If floor is oiled it is easier to sweep it properly. And there is the further advantage that the oil preserves the floor and makes it wear longer.

Sgd. Henry Conn,
Insp.
Extract from Report of Mr. R. H. Abraham, Undergraduate of the O. A. C., on the No. 1 School, Walpole Island.

No. 1 School, Walpole Island.

The school grounds are much too small, about 2/6 of an acre. The school is also much too small for the number of pupils. Size 17 x 20 x 10 = 4590 sq. ft. According to the Ontario Education Dept's Regulations there must be 250 cu. ft. for each pupil that would mean that the school was large enough for 18 pupils. The day I was there there were 34 present. This is rather important when we consider the number of Indians that die of consumption. Also the drinking arrangements at the school could be improved with a view to checking this disease. Each pupil could be provided with a cup as is done in many of the rural schools.

Sgd. R. H. Abraham.

FEATURES OF SUPERIORITY IN THE SILENT SANITARY SCHOOL DESKS

It is Sanitary.—The one-piece standard, with its perfect shield for the book-box, presents no dust pockets or germ-breeding ledges, either inside or outside. Even the feet have been fitted with rubber caps so that round surfaces are prevented from catching dust, and germs cannot lodge.

Beauty of Design.—The prevailing idea of simplicity is splendidly carried out. The proportions are unusually graceful, and the desks make a fine appearance in the school room.

Comfort Curves.—The seat and back are so shaped that they insure restfulness, at the same time keeping the pupils body in proper position.

Strength—Construction.—By scientific calculation and practical test, we have distributed the weight so that the greatest possible strain is taken by the legs. This distribution ensures the essential feature of any school desk—a absolute rigidity.

Pest Rent and Protection Board.—This is thoroughly protected. Each end rests in an iron socket in the leg, and is further secured by screws passing through the iron standard into the floor. The board is made of hard wood, so that the dust slides off, and cannot accumulate. This also acts as a protection board, preventing one pupil from annoying the pupil in front and soiling his or her clothing.

NOISELESS AUTOMATIC SEAT HINGE

The Automatic Seat Hinge is absolutely noiseless and will not loosen. In operation, the parts automatically tighten themselves.

Figure "A" shows the parts of the "Sanitary Noiseless" Hinge.

The ball on the inside of the seat arm casting (1) rests in the socket in the hub of the seat bearing (2). The hardened steel roller (3) rests in the hollow (4) of the hub. This roller bears against the eccentric (5) as the seat is lowered or raised. The bolt (6) passes through the seat arm casting and the hub, and is held in place by the nut (7). The nut lock (8) prevents the seat (7) from working loose.

The seat arm and bearings operate entirely on the hub, and the bolt is used only to hold the parts in place. The construction of this full arm and bearing system (instead of the usual seat movement), and the hardened steel roller working against the eccentric, gives a gradually increasing resistance until the seat is brought to a full stop. This permits such perfect adjustment of the parts that the hinge is absolutely frictionless and noiseless. The greatest strain on any hinge is when the seat is brought to a full stop. Any other hinge would be forced to bear the eccentricity is located. With this hinge any spreading where the eccentricities are located forces the hinge-strap more securely in place. The result is that the hinges, therefore, simply automatically tightens the parts.

Figure B shows the hinge with part of the iron cut away so that you can see the position of the hardened steel roller and the eccentricity of the seat arm bearing. Like metal, working against like metal, would rapidly wear away. The resilient steel roller, however, permits a slight yielding, so that the seat arm bearing is always kept in place. The hinge is absolutely noiseless, and its ingenious construction forces it to tighten itself when in operation.

Mr. Scott,

On October 26 last I made an inspection of the Walpole Island Agency building repairs and while there made inquiries with respect to condition of school affairs at that place, which are anything but satisfactory.

It was reported in 1915 that on this reserve there were 120 children of school age; 86 pupils enrolled in the school and an average attendance of 48 at the reserve schools and 7 at industrial schools. The enrollment at the village school (No.1) in 1915 was 50 with an average attendance of 24 during the year and as the school building provided accommodation for 18 only, plans were made for the erection of an addition to this building to accommodate 40 pupils, but owing to the tenders being unduly high the addition to the school was not provided. I am of the opinion, however, that a new school should be built here as soon as possible after the opening up of spring to provide accommodation for all children of school age in the vicinity of the No.1 school, and that the attendance of all pupils be enforced regularly. To do this the Agent would have to act as truant officer and be responsible to the Department for the regular attendance of the pupils.

The teacher might report to the agent at least once a week or oftener the names of all delinquents with particulars as to attendance and the agent should then enforce attendance or punish the persons responsible for the pupil's absence, which
which would ensure regular attendance. This is the action taken in respect to boarding and industrial schools and should work satisfactorily in day schools.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to Mr. Ogilvie's report on the Walpole Island Schools I beg to say that, as regards the attendance, it has certainly been going from bad to worse. They have a truant officer there and the teachers have done their best to keep the attendance up with no encouragement from the Agent, in fact it is a question whether he has not been a hindrance. I judge this from his own reports, as nothing apparently affords him greater pleasure than noting the falling off of the attendance. He has never said anything about assisting the teachers in this direction and his attitude towards them has been such that Miss Wilson, the teacher of the No. 1 School, has sent in her resignation, asking that it take effect on the first proximo. Miss Warnock, the teacher of the No. 2 School, resigned after the summer holidays and Mr. Cork, who has taken her place, is not satisfactory to Mr. McCallum.

Mr. Public School Inspector Conn, in his report
On the No. 1 School states as follows:— "The pupils who were present showed satisfactory proficiency and are undoubtedly making good progress. The teacher is to be commended for the attention she is giving to hygiene and personal cleanliness. I examined samples of the pupils' works in plain sewing and am very pleased with the work that is being done. I believe the teacher is making efforts to secure better attendance, but she is not meeting with much success."

Miss Wilson may have offended some of the parents on account of her desire to have the children cleanly in their habits and person and from what I can learn Mr. McCallum is rather pleased than otherwise at the teacher's unpopularity. Mr. Inspector, in a previous report on this school states that Miss Wilson is a capable teacher and doing efficient work and that he is pleased with the attentionshe is devoting to physical culture and hygiene. He adds that Miss Wilson is difficult to get on with. Mr. McCallum apparently never made an effort to get on with her, in fact ever since she has been there he has done what he can to make her position untenable and I am of the opinion that he is prepared to do the same with Mr. Cork.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Public School Inspector Conn, in a report on his recent inspection of the No. 1 School on the Walpole Island Reserve, states that there are 56 pupils enrolled and the maximum attendance this year is 47, while on the basis of 250 cubic feet per pupil, the air space required, the class-room only has accommodation for 18 pupils. The Inspector states that, if the present attendance keeps up, it will be necessary to put the pupils on half time during the winter, as it will be impossible to accommodate them all at one time.

Mr. McKay, who recently returned from Sarnia, informs me that this school is very much overcrowded, the children being packed in as close as they can be seated. Both the teacher and the agent spoke to him about the necessity for more accommodation.

A new school building is badly needed at this point, as the present building, besides being too small, is very old and in poor repair.

In June, 1916, tenders were called for alterations and additions to this school, plans having been made to provide accommodation for 40 pupils. Only one tender was received, which was unduly high, and the work was not carried out.

The Chippewas of Walpole Island have about $16,000.00 at the credit of capital in their band funds and they could provide the money required to erect a suitable building.

Mr.
Mr. McKay states that the teacher and the agent suggested that, until a new building is erected, accommodation could be provided for all the children in the parish hall. This building is owned by the English Church authorities and, if a few repairs were made, it would be quite suitable and large enough to provide the necessary accommodation. It might be well to instruct the Agent to arrange with the church authorities for the renting of this building and to have the seats and equipment in the present school moved there. The teacher informed Mr. McKay that there would be no difficulty about making arrangements with the church authorities for renting the building. The only expense involved in using the parish hall would be the payment of the rent and the providing of a few more desks. I may say that Mr. McKay agrees that this would be the best arrangement that could be made, pending the erection of a new building.

As the building in which the No. 1 Indian Day School on Walpole Island is at present conducted is very old and too small to accommodate the number of children who attend it has been suggested to the Department that it might be possible to obtain the use of the parish hall, which would be quite suitable, to carry on the work until such time as a new school building is erected, which it is planned to do in the near future.

I have to request Your Lordship to be good enough to state whether there would be any objection to the Department obtaining the use of the parish hall for school purposes and, if not, the amount of rent per month that would be charged the Department for the use of the same. If the parish hall can be secured it will simplify the situation at present existing there. The desks and other equipment at the present school could be moved and placed in the hall.

I will be pleased if Your Lordship will give this matter your early attention and forward a reply as to whether you will consent to the parish hall being obtained for school purposes, or not.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I had an interview with the Indian authorities in reference to renting the Parish Hall at Walpole Island for a School, and we discussed the matter at great length. Considering that the Hall would be used five days of the week, and much wear and tear would inevitably ensue, notwithstanding the greatest care, it is felt that $20.00 a month is a fair rent to ask from the Department. Of course, it is understood that the Hall will be free on Saturdays and Sundays for the use of the Congregation, and also that the expense of heating and cleaning the Hall will belong to the Department.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 29th ultimo in further reference to the question of renting the parish hall at Walpole Island for school purposes.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will accept the offer made by the Indian authorities and will pay a rental of $20.00 per month for the period the hall is used for school purposes. It is understood that the hall will be free on Saturdays and Sundays for the use of the congregation. The Department will undertake the expense of the heating during the days the school is in operation and will also be responsible for cleaning the hall while in use by the pupils. The Department will assume payment of the rent at the above rate from January 1st, next, until such time as the new school building is ready for occupation.

Instructions are being sent to our Agent to have the equipment in the present building transferred to the hall and to have it ready for the re-opening of the school after the Christmas holidays.

I beg to thank Your Lordship for the trouble you have taken in this matter.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Sir,

As the building in which the No. 1 Indian Day School on Walpole Island is at present conducted is too small to accommodate the number of children who attend, the Department has arranged with His Lordship the Bishop of Huron for the renting of the parish hall from the vestry of St. John's Church at a rental of $20.00 per month from the first day of January next. It has been represented to the Department that this is the most suitable arrangement that can be made to provide accommodation for all the Indian children until such time as a new building is erected, which it is planned to have done in the near future.

I have, therefore, to request that, during the coming Christmas holidays, you will make the necessary arrangements to have the equipment in the present building transferred to the parish hall. The desks should be transferred and arranged in suitable order and also, if possible, the blackboards should be transferred and set up in the hall. It may be that some new desks will be required to provide seating for all the pupils and, if so, you should forward a list showing the sizes and the number of each size required. The name and address of the manufacturer of the present desks should also be given, so that any new desks ordered can be of the same kind as those at present in the school.

In renting this hall it is understood with the church authorities that the hall will be free to them on Saturdays and Sundays for the use of the congregation, also that the expense of heating and cleaning the hall during the days the school is in operation is to be undertaken by the Department.

It is hoped that you will attend to the matter of having the equipment transferred and the hall ready for the teacher to resume duties after the holidays. It might be well to consult her in the arranging of the desks, etc., in the parish hall. Any expenses that are incurred by you in having the removal made will be paid upon the receipt of properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure.

Any fuel which may be on hand at the old school should be transferred for the use of heating the hall, and, if a further supply is required, you will be good enough to inform the Department of the amount of the same and the price at which it can be obtained, when authority will be granted for its purchase.

You will be good enough to forward at the end of

Sir,

Walpole Island Agency.

In reply to your letter of the 5th inst., and previous correspondence in regard to the No.1 Indian Day School, on Walpole Island, and with reference to the renting of the Parish Hall, for school purposes during the winter, beg leave to advise that I attended a meeting of General Council held by the Indians, on Walpole Island, in the Parish Hall on Monday, Dec. 29th, and would not unhesitatingly say that it will be impossible to heat the Parish Hall during the winter. I am very doubtful if it could be successfully heated even with two stoves, as it would necessitate the purchase of a stove along with a great deal of extra fuel, and would further advise and recommend that as the average attendance will not likely increase during the winter months we'd advise that school be conducted in the present building until a new school is erected.

Further I learned that the Indians hold a great many meetings in the Parish Hall, and believe if we move the school to the Parish Hall, it would be a great deal of confusion.

Awaiting your reply, I remain,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to the renting of the parish hall for the purpose of providing accommodation for the pupils of the No. 1 School on the Walpole Island Reserve during the present winter.

In reply I beg to say that the Department understood, before making arrangements for the renting of the hall, that it would be quite suitable for school purposes in all respects. An officer of this Department, who visited Sarnia last fall, was informed by both the teacher and yourself that the parish hall could be heated and made comfortable.

You were instructed by official letter of December 5th, last, to make the necessary arrangements to have the equipment in the present building transferred to the parish hall. As it is understood that you visit Walpole Island each week there has been unnecessary delay in informing the Department that you now consider the building unsuitable, as it will be impossible to heat it during the winter.

In view of the report which you now furnish regarding the unsuitableness of the parish hall and in which you recommend that, as the average attendance will not likely increase during the winter months, it would be advisable that the school be conducted in the old school building until such time as a new building is erected, the Department will approve of this arrangement being carried out. You should assist the teacher in making the best possible arrangement for the accommodation of the children in the present building.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, in which you advise that the work of constructing the new school building on Walpole Island be postponed until next year.

In reply I beg to say that the Department considers that, owing to the cost of material at the present time, it would be well to postpone this work until next year. You should state, however, what disposition is being made of the lumber and other material that is being saved for the building. This should be stored in some secure place, where it will not deteriorate or be lost.

Dear Mr Scott,

In connection with building the New School No 1 at Walpole Island I beg to say that I am of the opinion that the best way to have it built would be by day labour. As you are aware we are constructing this school from lumber sawn from timber from the Indians own woods.

I would recommend that we employ two white men (one to act as working foreman) and secure the rest of the labour required from among the Indians. I know of a thoroughly competent man whose services I believe could be secured if I could speak to him soon.

I expect that the Lumber will be ready to use about the first of June.

I would be glad if you would advise me as soon as possible regarding this.

I remain,

March 21st, 1921.

Hon. Sir James Lougheed -

On January 22nd, 1920 your predecessor in office approved of the erection of a two-roomed school house on Walpole Island the cost to be paid from band funds. The Indians themselves were to cut the lumber from their supply on the reserve and have it sawn at a private mill belonging to one of the bands. Most of this lumber has been taken out and our Agricultural Representative, Mr. R. H. Abraham, who visited Ottawa lately, reports that this material will be ready for use by the first of June next.

In view of the fact that we are supplying such a large proportion of the material he has recommended that the work be done by day labour. It appears that there are some competent workmen among the Indians of Walpole Island and it would be only necessary for us to engage two white men, one as foreman and the other as assistant. Mr. Abraham states that he is acquainted with a very competent man whom he would heartily recommend.

I am disposed to think that owing to the locality of the proposed building on the island, Mr. Abraham's suggestion is a good one, and that we would erect the building at a less cost than if we called for public tenders. As the estimated cost is less than £5,000.00 under the statute we can follow this course and with your approval I would propose to do so.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM

Honourable Sir James Lougheed,

In March last you approved the erection of a two-roomed school house on Walpole Island, the cost of which was to be paid from the funds of the band. The Indians supplied the lumber, which was cut on the Reserve, and the work was done by day labour, under the supervision of our Agricultural Representative, Mr. R. H. Abraham.

Mr. Abraham states that the building will be completed and ready for occupation by the middle of next month, and has asked that the desks and school furnishings be supplied. There are about 100 children of school age who should attend, and the two class rooms provide seating accommodation for 40 children in each room, and it is intended to provide desks for that number. The following supplies will be required, and will cost approximately the sum of $1100.00, viz:

- 80 single desks.............. $936.00
- 2 teachers' desks............. 50.00
- 2 teachers' chairs............ 20.00
- Visitors' chairs.............. 34.00
- 2 bookcases................... 62.00

$1100.00.

As the cost of erecting the building will be about $5,000, the funds at the credit of the band will not allow for the expenditure involved in the purchase of the above school furniture. The appropriation for Indian education can provide the necessary funds, and I would request your authority for the above expenditure to be approved.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

These desks should be a cherry colour and ink-wells should be supplied with all desks.

The desks should be shipped in a knocked-down condition, securely packed, with all the necessary parts supplied to assemble and fasten them to the floor. All the above should be delivered at Wallaceburg, Ontario, at the price quoted by you in your tender; the aggregate amount being $943.50, plus sales tax.

You will be good enough, when shipment has been made, to immediately notify Mr. Abraham, whose post office address is Chatham, Ont., of the date of shipment in order that he can arrange to accept delivery. When these supplies are shipped, you should, at the same time, forward your account in duplicate to Mr. Abraham, who will be instructed, upon receipt of these desks, if in good condition, to certify the account and forward to the Department when payment will be made.

The above school furniture is required for a new two-roomed school which is nearing completion on the Walpole Island Indian Reserve, and I will be pleased if this order will receive your early attention.

OTTAWA, December 6th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing a communication from Mrs. Florence Macdonald, teacher of the No. 1 school on Walpole Island, requesting that a grant be provided to purchase Christmas gifts for the pupils of her school.

In reply I beg to say that you may authorise Mrs. Macdonald to expend an amount not to exceed $12.50 in the purchase of these supplies. She should obtain itemised accounts, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, which she should hand to you. You will then be good enough to certify these accounts and forward to the Department for payment.

As you have already been informed, the sum of $6.00, the amount asked for by the teacher, has been approved for the purchase of suitable gifts for the children of the No. 2 school.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Neighan -

The Department has had under consideration the erection of a new school building on the portion of the Malpole Island reserve occupied chiefly by the Chippewas. The present building, which has become quite dilapidated and beyond repair, has adequate accommodation, as required by the Provincial regulations, only for about twenty children, whereas there are in this section approximately seventy-five children of school age. At the present time the enrolment is almost sixty and the average attendance over forty. We made arrangements this winter to use a public hall on the reserve for school purposes, but unfortunately it was found that the building could not be heated. As it is, some of the children are unable to attend, and the teacher proposed some time ago to adopt a half-day system. One teacher cannot give efficient instruction to so many Indian children and I would propose to erect a two-roomed building and provide salary for an additional teacher.

This band has a capital of £16,000.00 and I would recommend that we expend therefrom an amount sufficient to erect the building and purchase a new site. There is considerable timber on the lands belonging to the Indians in common, and there are two saw-mills on the reserve. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, of the 18th ultimo, with reference to complaint forwarded to the Department by Mrs. Grace Savage, Principal, of the No. 1 Indian Bay School, Walpole Island, reporting that the Pipes, in the Jr. Room, are not giving satisfaction. In reply, beg to advise that I took this matter up, as advised, with Mr. Zavitz, Hardware Merchant, of Wallaceburg, Ont., and that he recommended cutting a hole, 3in. in diameter, in the 2nd length of pipe, above the stove. This hole would admit air from the school room, which he says, in many cases, prevents the smoke from condensing. And, if this does not give result, the only remedy would be, to build another chimney on the side of the school, that we might be able to install a shorter string of pipes, which would eliminate the condensing of creosote, and smoke. I might add, that I believe that we have enough dry wood at this school, to carry us through the winter, which I believe will also give us less trouble with smoke and creosote.

Dear Sir,

Would you kindly send an order, as in former years, to purchase Christmas gifts in London for the children of this school? There are 65 pupils enrolled so I would ask that twenty dollars ($20) be added. That is $1 per dollar for each pupil.

As the Walpole Island Post Office has been closed, would you kindly make arrangements to have a special route box put up at the school. Otherwise a nine mile drive is necessary in order to procure the school correspondence.

With regard to the hot lunches, kindly inform me at your earliest convenience if it is the policy of the Department that these should be served. Last year the pupils were served with hot cocoa at noon. Now however the
attendance has so increased that it would be necessary to have more lunches, a moderately priced coal oil stove and an issue of cocoa and biscuits or an allowance for same. We would willingly instruct and supervise the older pupils in the preparation and serving of these lunches should the Department deem them advisable.

You will be pleased to learn that since the fires have been wrapped with asbestos, there is no bother now with smoke. The placing of the two ventilators in the floors of the upstairs rooms in the teacher's residence, has completely solved the heating arrangements.

Sir:

We are not prepared to authorize any further expenditure for this purpose, except, if a number of cups to serve the cocoa are needed, you may purchase and supply one dozen.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the installation of a rural mail box and the condition of the school pump at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School.

Regarding the mail box, I beg to say that in official letter dated December 9th, last, we instructed Mr. Agent Paul to take this matter up with the proper local post office authorities and arrange to secure a box and have it set up at a convenient point. We informed him that the Department would pay the cost of the box and any expenses in having it installed upon receipt of properly certified vouchers from him covering the cost. Please take this matter up with Mr. Paul, referring him to our letter, with a view to having him take immediate action to obtain the same.

Regarding the repairs to the pump, we were informed by Mr. Abraham, who visited the department yesterday, that the services of a man were secured to make the necessary repairs. It is, therefore, hoped that this has been attended to by this time.

I may say that we wrote the Agent yesterday relative to a change in the janitor. Mr. Abraham suggested the name of Mrs. Coonoe, who lives near the school, and stated that he thought she would perform the duties satisfactorily. We asked Mr. Paul to consult you in this matter, and, if you were both satisfied that a change is advisable, the Department will approve of the appointment of Mrs. Coonoe. The Agent was instructed to inform the new janitor regarding the duties to be performed and also that the work had to be carried out to your satisfaction. I hope that you and the Agent will be able to arrange this matter satisfactorily and that the new janitor, if one is appointed, would be prepared to take up duties on the last possible date.

I presume that the Agent is arranging for the supplying of the mattresses and bedding required.

Your obedient servant,

Madam:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, relative to the various matters mentioned by you in connection with the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department did not receive the requisition for school supplies which you state you handed to the Agent early in January, last. We are instructing him to forward this requisition as soon as possible. I may say that a requisition is now being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send you 2 boxes of chalk and 1 dozen black board brushes.

Regarding the tinting of the walls of the classrooms, we are instructing Mr. Paul to arrange to have the walls tinted during the Easter holidays, using a cream colour or some shade that will not show the dirt. After the tinting has been done, he is to arrange to have the floors thoroughly scrubbed and oiled, also the windows washed.

Regarding the janitor services, we are again drawing Mr. Paul's attention to our instructions of January 20th, last, authorizing him to appoint a new incumbent for this work. We are instructing him to give this matter his prompt attention and to consult you in the matter. We suggested to him in January the name of Mrs. Oconee whom Mr. Abraham stated would perform the work satisfactorily. He is to arrange with the person appointed to scrub the floors of the classrooms once each month. An increase in the salary usually allowed will be given to the new janitor, provided this scrubbing is done each month. It would be advisable for you, acting in conjunction with the Agent, to select a competent person to perform janitor services.

Any suggestions you may have regarding the tinting of the walls as to colour, etc., will no doubt be accepted by the Agent, as he has been requested to consult you in the matter. We hope that he will arrange for the appointment of a new janitor to begin June 1st of April, next, and also in due time arrange for the tinting and cleaning required, in order that the work can be completed during the coming Easter holidays.

I am enclosing herewith a few forms "Requisition for School Material", as requested.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education

Ottawa, March 9, 1925.

Sir:

We are informed that during the first week in January the teacher of the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School handed you a requisition for school supplies. This requisition has not yet reached the Department. It is considered that you should attend more promptly to these matters, and this requisition should be forwarded as soon as possible.

The interior walls of the classrooms are very dirty and smoky, occasioned by the defective chimneys and pipes before they were repaired. The Department would like you to arrange to have the classroom walls tinted during the coming Easter holidays. A cream colour or some shade that would not show the dirt should be put on. You should make arrangements so that this work can be commenced immediately after the school closes for the Easter holidays. You are to purchase all material required and arrange to have the work done by a competent person by day labour. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed.

After the tinting has been completed, you should arrange to have the floors thoroughly scrubbed and given a coat of oil. The windows should also be thoroughly cleaned. If there are double windows, they should be removed and properly stored when the weather becomes warmer.

The Department expects that you will see that this work is satisfactorily carried out during the Easter holidays. We are informing the teacher that you have been instructed to have the tinting of the walls of the classrooms carried out and the floors scrubbed and oiled.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of the material and time sheets, in duplicate, properly certified, should also be forwarded, when payment will be made. No unnecessary expense should be incurred in having the above work completed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, March 25, 1927.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 8th instant regarding the smoke conditions caused by the defective chimney at the No. 1 Indian Day School, Walpole Island. In this connection I have to inform you that Mr. H. H. Abraham was instructed to arrange to have a new brick chimney erected, in a suitable location in the building, during the coming Easter holidays. In a reply from him, dated the 19th instant, he stated that he was making the necessary arrangements and would have this chimney built. We regret the inconvenience that is being caused to the teachers and the pupils; but it is hoped that it will be possible to carry on without renting another place until such time as the new chimney is finished.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Ottawa, March 30, 1927.

Sir:

In your letter of the 9th instant you reported regarding the condition of the chimney at the Walpole Island No. 1 Day School, and you were informed by official letter of the 12th instant that this matter had been referred to Mr. R. E. Abraham. The Department wrote the late Mr. Abraham on that date, authorizing him to have a new brick chimney, suitably located, erected during the coming Easter holidays. In a letter dated the 15th instant, he replied stating that he was making the necessary arrangements to have the chimney built. The Department is not aware exactly what arrangements the late Mr. Abraham made, but it is not likely that he had done very much in regard to the matter.

It is most important that the erection of this new chimney be given early attention, and, in view of Mr. Abraham's death, I have to request that you will look after the matter personally, and make immediate arrangements for the purchase of the brick and the securing of the necessary labour.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
